review: "Love & Mercy" has some of the best acting I have seen from John Cusack, but there are script and direction weaknesses that make the story dull and incoherent at times. This story might have seen better told linearly.

"Love & Mercy" follows young and older Brian Wilson and his band, The Beach Boys. While we flash back and forth between the bands struggles and triumphs, and into the future where he is trying to find love and dealing with Schizophrenia, the film's deep vibes and meaningful visuals made me very emotional. Paul Dano is incredible in his portrayal of Brian Wilson and John Cusack plays his illness very well. Elizabeth Banks really felt like someone who had no idea how to handle this situation. In the end, "Love & Mercy" satisfies with brilliant writing, superb direction, and a story that is much more worth telling than I expected it to. I really loved watching this film and it displays amazing performances all around and celebrates their best music in style. This is not a film you should miss. Definitely worth it's praise.

Brian Wilson's records Pet Sounds and, in another story, falls in love with a car dealer.This film alternates between two stories of Brian Wilson's life, and both are compelling and incredibly well-acted. John Cusack and Paul Dano are at top form, and their performances are the highlights of this strong, interesting, and heartfelt film. Paul Giamatti plays older Wilson's psychiatrist cum legal guardian, who is scamming Wilson for his fortune and talent, and younger Wilson's Beach Boys brethren vie for control of the band, the artistic sense of which Wilson wants to take in new Beatles-imitation directions.For a while, I was so compelled by the pitch-perfect story-telling and wonderful performances that I considered whether Love and Mercy might be the best film of the year, better than Ex Machina, but no, sadly, Elizabeth Banks's role fall in to the "helping woman" cliche, and there are some objectiveless, wandering scenes that only Dano's talent makes interesting.Overall, God only know what would be a better Brian Wilson biopic.

In the vast ocean of clichï¿½d rock star biopics, this plunge into the troubled but brilliant mind of Beach Boys' leader Brian Wilson wisely tries to avoid much of the saccharin and focuses only in two of the most important events that led Wilson to his much publicized mental disruptions, without neglecting his sparks of genius, both instances are treated with visual and sonic sensitivity. Paul Dano and John Cusack manage to define the man, separating the young persona with a stubborn but evolving artistic vision from his broken down older self, who has ceased to strive for perfection, but now does for acceptance.
'Love and Mercy' provides both an intimate and potent look into the mind of a unique artist, played superbly by both Dano and Cusack.

Paul Dano and John Cusack offer two exceptional performances as Wilson in two distinct (and at times even contrasting) stages of his life, and this insightful biopic is very well directed, beautifully photographed and filled with the wonderful music of The Beach Boys.

Breaking away from conventional biopic structure, LOVE & MERCY is a well-crafted and deeply-intriguing examination into the life and mind of a uniquely-talented yet tortured individual. While Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys makes for a strong central character - with Paul Dano giving an off-kilter performance that further solidifies his skill in tackling emotionally-complicated subjects as well as a resurgent turn by John Cusack, Bill Pohlad's directorial debut displays a surprising discipline towards characterization as it never allows the narrative to stray too far, thus providing a film that is insightful and sympathetic yet filled with smooth editing, fun music, and a distinct and very fitting visual palette. Specifically, the scenes of Wilson's recording sessions in the studio with both his band as well as the studio musicians are some of the best moments in the film; they effectively give viewers a glimpse of authenticity and a seemingly exclusive behind-the-scenes access despite it being a re-creation - undoubtedly an impressive execution.

It is 1966. While returning from a successful tour, Brian Wilson(Paul Dano) of the Beach Boys suffers a debilitating anxiety attack on the flight home. So, he opts out of the Japan leg of the tour in favor of recording some new music for the band. Now all he has to do is figure out how to get the horse inside of the recording studio.It is 1985. Brian Wilson(John Cusack) would like to buy a car. And not just any car, mind you. Which Melinda Ledbetter(Elizabeth Banks), a salesperson, would like to help him with. That happens under the very watchful eye of Dr. Eugene Landy(Paul Giamatti)."Love and Mercy" is a thoughtful movie about the intersection between madness and genius which also takes the time to redeem the critical reputation of the Beach Boys. The story is set over two time periods which are linked by two surprisingly matching performances from Paul Dano and John Cusack.(Dano plays Brian struggling to communicate while Cusack is the empty husk of what is left.) While each time period is clearly demarcated by its respective fashions, they are joined in one mindbending segment late in the film. The problems arise in how the movie plays out, namely in seeking as pat a resolution as humanly possible for mental illness for which there is no real cure. And I never quite grasped the importance of the will in all of this.

It's much better, and far more moving, than I anticipated. Like most biopics, it does occasionally get bogged down in needless melodrama but unlike most biopics it never gets lost there. The dual narratives focusing on two parts of Wilson's life compliment each other nicely and the small scale focus ensures that "Love & Mercy" never ends up being another montage movie that only focuses on events rather than the characters.

As Pet Sounds is the perfect album so is Love and Mercy the perfectly created biopic of Brian Wilson's whacked-out genius . Dano and Cusack are terrific as young and older Brian. The re-creation of the studio sessions of PS and SMILE are pure magic. Elizabeth Banks (very stunning in an 80's way) plays his second wife Melinda who is Brian's loving antidote to an overbearing father Murry Wilson (Bill Camp is great) bloodsucking shrink Eugene Landy (bad wig Paul Giamatti) and irritatingly short-sighted cousin Mike Love. This one made me SMILE big time! Best movie of 2015 by a wide margin. (6-13-15)

Love & Mercy shattered all my expectations and gave me a viewing experience to treasure for a lifetime. Brian Wilson is truly an admirable music icon, and both John Cusack and Paul Dano gave outstanding performances.PS (Also some sort of disclaimer)Just putting it out there, nothing can beat The Beatles.

A celebration of one of the most brilliant minds in the history of music, this film boasts two top tier performances from Paul Dano and John Cusack, and a fascinating look at Brian Wilson's songwriting process.

A definitve movie for any Beach Boys fan and for any music fan in general. The story of Brian Wilson shown here is a deep and complex as the real man himself. While critics will rightfully tell of the extraordinary performance of Paul Dano has the younger Brian, don't count out John Cusack as the older Brian. Surrounded by a strong supporting cast of Elizabeth Banks and Paul Giamatti, who while a great actor needs to not get stuck playing the "well meaning" villians between this and Straight Outta Compton, and a unique style by first time director Bill Pohlad that makes the movie more than anyone could of thought. The only real flaw may just be a personal opinion of my own in that it kind of feel with the scenes between Brian nd other members of the Beach Boys in the past seemed a little off. Other than that, I feel this is a movie that people should see.

There was a brief time in my life when The Beach Boys was my favorite band. While everyone else had KISS and Pink Floyd stickers on their notebooks, I proclaimed the greatness of The Beach Boys! I had few friends. I digress. This is really a pretty fantastic biopic, despite only focusing on a couple very specific periods in Brian Wilson's life. John Cusack was amazing, as always, but as big a Cusack fan as I am, I thought he was miscast. Dano was good too, and Banks could have lit a fire in a eunuch's loins. Great film, especially if you're a fan. Plus a half star 'cause fucking Beach Boys!

A very interesting and well-acted biopic on Brian Wilson played by Paul Dano in his younger years and John Cusack in his older years. Cusack doesn't particularly look like Wilson, but his performance as an older Beach Boy fighting demons is captivating. So is Paul Dano. Let's not leave out Elizabeth Banks who plays Wilson's love interest and Paul Giamatti who is scary as Wilson's medical guardian. The music will bring fans back to the glory days of The Beach Boys and new insight to one of its members whose life was anything but sunshine. Grade: A-

A fine line often separates genius and madness; the story of Beach Boy Brian Wilson is a prime example of that. Besides his struggles with mental illness, Brian Wilson was used and abused by both his father and his psychiatrist during different periods of his life. Both narratives are masterfully juxtaposed in this film, fueled by the strong performances of both Paul Dano and John Cusak. Both give a striking rendition of the film's protagonist, while Paul Giamatti is at his villainous best as Eugene Landy. Love & Mercy raises the bar for what a music biopic should be.

Dano's performance makes real the era and the raggedy tragedy of Wilson's art and life. I especially liked the scenes in the studio. Watching somebody make art in the movies is typically a hot mess, but here, we see a process, made coherent because we know where it's going. I'm less enamored of the Cusack segments, bringing the story into the 90s when he is rescued from a Svengali huckster psychologist, not only because Cusack's look is so different, but because there was so much missing between the different slices of Wilson's life that the latter felt contrived and conflated. Which it is, if you read Wilson's bio. Oh well, it's not perfect, but the music is, and the scenes where the music is central are just so wonderful for this nostalgic geezer who lived through it all. I used to go to the Beach Boys concert every Christmas. Until, of course, the Beetles.

Catnip to us Boomers who love the Beach Boys, of course, but it's SO much more than that. We rarely get to see "close ups" of a creative genius at work OR get to see the price paid for art. Paul Dano is a revelation. Elizabeth Banks gets to show off her "chops" beyond Effie (Hunger Games) and Gayle (Pitch Perfect). Paul Giamatti gets to go "full Giamatti" and that's always fun. If a new generation discovers "Pet Sounds," so much the better.
What a great movie and The Beach Boys soundtrack was wonderful. Wilson underwent terrible emotional pain and depression as a shrink tries to destroy him, both financially and emotionally.

Fans will love it, and newcomers will be drawn in. A unique look at the torment of genius that is Brian Wilson and the Beach Boys. I Can Hear Music, and God Only Knows but this has some Good Vibrations

Solid film that I enjoyed more than I thought I would. Love & Mercy is the story of the Beach Boy's Brian Wilson played by John Cusack depicted in the late 80's and Paul Dano as young Brian Wilson during the 60's and 70's. The movie goes over Wilson's creative emergence during his time with the Beach Boys and the crazy mental illnesses he battled for the rest of his life. The film is told in a series of flashbacks while Wilson meets a lady named Melinda (Elizabeth Banks) who finds Wilson's life style to be super puzzling. Because of his mental breakdowns Wilson is under guardianship by Dr. Eugene Landy (Paul Giamatti) who is forcing Wilson to take more and more medication and controlling every aspect of his life. It soon becomes apparent in the present time that Melinda and Brian need to break away from Landy. In the past we go over how Wilson discovered different sounds and his downfall with drugs and alcohol. It's a nice little bio pic that works a lot of the times especially the scenes from the past. Each scene from the past sets up something that happens in the present and at these times its a much more smoother riding picture. The present time just doesn't wrap up nice enough. I felt like the movie had another twenty minutes or so. Overall, solid film. If you like the Beach Boys at all give this one a look!

Paul Dano and John Cusack star as young and old Brian Wilson, respectively, in Love and Mercy. It's basically the story of Brian Wilson, from Wilson's perspective.I had no idea what Wilson went through; it's really interesting. Love gave this musical artist a new lease on life, after he lost his rights to psychiatrist and manipulator Dr. Eugene Landy. When Brian meets car saleswoman Melinda Ledbetter and falls for her, something special happens for them. Melinda soon comes to see that Dr. Landy exerts an unhealthy control over Brian's life, frequently overmedicating him and preventing him from having normal interactions with his family and friends and making normal choices, and using abusive tactics to control everyone around him, especially Brian.With the help of staff Gloria, Melinda finds the evidence she needs to show Brian's family what's really going on, and basically saves his life. Dr. Landy ultimately loses his long held control over Brian along with his medical license in the state of CA. Brian regains control over the right to choose his own destiny, and he and Melinda choose each other.The movie also takes an interesting look at Brian's younger days, when he was churning out songs, experimenting with drugs, living with his first love, and spending a lot of time with his brothers and the rest of the Beach Boys. It also looks at his relationship with his father, and what living and song writing with his mental illness was like for him. The guy felt some torment, but he found a lot of satisfaction in his craft. He got to do what he loved: make music! And he's still doing it, decades later, with his love Melinda by his side. Brian Wilson's story has a positive upbeat turnout, light at the end of the tunnel.Of course, this is one-sided. Dr. Landy's side is not told.For people with mental illness, those with family and/or friends willing to fight for them have a better outcome, from what I've seen, than those who get sucked into "the system" with no one on their side. I know of a lady, a friend of a friend, who, like Brain, lost her right to make her own decisions. Her house was sold to pay for her institutionalization, and she is a lifer in her institution, because she was depressed after her husband died and was lucky enough to receive "help". She fills a bed, and social security pays the institution for their services, so she will never be allowed to leave and have a normal life. Her rights to self determination will not be returned to her, for money reasons, although she is not a threat to herself or anyone else and is no longer grieving for her husband. She is heavily medicated, has a poor quality of life, and has no right to decide any of it. If she wanted a second opinion, no one gives her that option, because she has no rights.Too bad every depressed or otherwise mentally ill person doesn't have a Melinda Ledbetter to fight for them.

A crittically lauded and unfortunately underseen gem by the masses, Love and Mercy is a look into the live of Brian Wilson at two separate points in his life, as he reaches the heights of his productivity with the Beach Boys as his mental health rapidly disintegrates and him gradually emerging in a more subdued way as he is being managed by a seedy manager looking to profit by his ill health after years of his self imposed sit in only to be brought back to the world by the new love in his life portrayed by Elizabeth Banks. Both Cusack and Dano do really great suitaly portraying the twitches and difficulties that Wilson had to battle through, as well as portraying how Wilson came up with some of the most iconic soundscapes of the California rock sound, while Giamanti has the market cornered on corrupt music managers, A must see for all music fans :)
Before seeing this I hated Dr. Eugene based on stories I heard about him, he was a fucker. Very good movie!
Magnificent movie about the Beach Boys with incredible performances of both lead actors.

A moving portrait of the musical genius of Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys, the demons that followed him from youth to middle age, and the woman whose love turned his life around. Great performances by Paul Dano (young Brian) and John Cusack (older Brian).
Bolstered by excellent performances from the most everyone involved, Love and Mercy is effective as an introduction to the Beach Boys (for me, at least) and as satisfying drama. Verdict: A

"Love & Mercy" has some of the best acting I have seen from John Cusack, but there are script and direction weaknesses that make the story dull and incoherent at times. This story might have seen better told linearly.

A definitve movie for any Beach Boys fan and for any music fan in general. The story of Brian Wilson shown here is a deep and complex as the real man himself. While critics will rightfully tell of the extraordinary performance of Paul Dano has the younger Brian, don't count out John Cusack as the older Brian. Surrounded by a strong supporting cast of Elizabeth Banks and Paul Giamatti, who while a great actor needs to not get stuck playing the "well meaning" villians between this and Straight Outta Compton, and a unique style by first time director Bill Pohlad that makes the movie more than anyone could of thought. The only real flaw may just be a personal opinion of my own in that it kind of feel with the scenes between Brian nd other members of the Beach Boys in the past seemed a little off. Other than that, I feel this is a movie that people should see.

Love & Mercy is fascinating when it takes apart the nuts and bolts of Wilson's songs, showing how he used the music studio as his instrument while striving to outdo The Beatles in harmonic daring. But it's more of a psychological character study than a rock-music biopic, and Love & Mercy is unnervingly effective.
Interesting story of music and mental illness.

Trippy. That's the word that comes to mind. Trippy with harmonies. And sad. Such a talent, pained with sensitivities and huge exploitation for decades. Makes me happy to know he got credit for his skills and music in his life time. Not every artist is so lucky!

Really I had no idea what Brian Wilson had gone through so this film was a giant eye opener. The best part about this film though is that unlike most biopics of famous musicians, this film concentrates solely on the Wilson character completely. It doesn't vere off to the band or to the "tough times" blah blah blah but soley stays with Wilson. The combo of Dano/Cusauck is unbelievably effective showing the progress from child star to completely broken adult. Fascinating film.

I had a strange realization watching the film... There were a couple older ladies sitting behind me who chatted a little during the movie (not enough to ruin it really), and they seemed very familiar with the events of Brian Wilson's life - when Gene Landy shows up they knew immediately, and a couple other times. But it almost made the film like a MCU movie where there's this world of the film that people are familiar with the characters already. Just a note, seemed like an odd epiphany I had.But! The film itself was VERY good. Paul Dano and John Cusack both brought different but appropriate energies to the different versions of Brian Wilson - eerily so on Paul Dano's performance. It was crazy to see his mannerisms and voice coming out of Paul Dano's boyish face, when Brian Wilson for much of my life has been an older man. Either way, they both brought great skill into portraying the visionary musician.The other stand-out parts of the film were the incredible sound design and the non-linear editing. The story hops back and forth between the 60?s and the 80?s in a way that really keenly tells the story of Brian Wilson's mental decline and later abusive relationship with Landy. The key moments that really triggered some innovative storytelling were Brian's first acid trip, Mike Love's disgruntled reaction to Pet Sounds, the development of Good Vibrations, and then of course, Elizabeth Banks's Melinda Ledbetter taking down Landy with the help of the Wilson family near the end. THE SOUND DESIGN THOUGH. it just so evocatively displays, in tandem with Paul Dano, the "music in his head" enigma and really contributes as a tool to the storytelling throughout the entire film.It might be tough to find (limited release I think?) but definitely worth seeing in a theater with good sound so you can be totally immersed. It was great, would definitely recommend!

Meh. Elisabeth Banks shines through this film that I felt hit you over the head with all it points. Plus I have never been a big Beach Boys fan except for the excellent Pet Sounds. A lot of scenery chewing by Paul Giammatti and John Cusak while Paul Dano is serviceable as a younger Brian Wilson

The best biopics don't attempt to tell the whole story. And thankfully "Love & Mercy" adheres to this adage. Instead, the film focuses on two key moments in Brian Wilson's life: as her conceives of the group's transformative sounds and of his rebirth two decades later when he is saved from the grip of his controversial, 24-hour therapist Dr Eugene Landy (Paul Giamatti). This is helped by the decision to cast two actors to portray Wilson: Paul Dano and John Cusack, both of who do a good job. Elizabeth Banks, too, gives a good performance as Wilson's now-wife, Melinda Ledbetter (Elizabeth Banks), who he met inside a Cadillac showroom. The other star is the '80s clothes and dï¿½cor that features in the latter story, which is a retrospective feast.

Love & Mercy shattered all my expectations and gave me a viewing experience to treasure for a lifetime. Brian Wilson is truly an admirable music icon, and both John Cusack and Paul Dano gave outstanding performances.PS (Also some sort of disclaimer)Just putting it out there, nothing can beat The Beatles.

'Love & Mercy' is helped by the fact that it doesn't play as a straightforward biopic. Skipping the usual 'rise to fame' story of The Beach Boys and focussing its attention on the peculiar life and psyche of one of its members.At the one end we have Paul Dano slowly slipping into madness, while at the other end we have John Cusack desperately trying to climb out of it.It doesn't quite cut deep enough (Paul Giamatti's manipulative Eugene Landy is underused and Banks isn't much more than a pretty guardian angel) but it's an interesting portrait of an equally intriguing musical genius.

There was a brief time in my life when The Beach Boys was my favorite band. While everyone else had KISS and Pink Floyd stickers on their notebooks, I proclaimed the greatness of The Beach Boys! I had few friends. I digress. This is really a pretty fantastic biopic, despite only focusing on a couple very specific periods in Brian Wilson's life. John Cusack was amazing, as always, but as big a Cusack fan as I am, I thought he was miscast. Dano was good too, and Banks could have lit a fire in a eunuch's loins. Great film, especially if you're a fan. Plus a half star 'cause fucking Beach Boys!

88%Balancing the depiction of Brian Wilson's boundless creativity with his later mistreatment by Eugene Landy, Love & Mercy is a revealing drama that also relies on the outstanding performances from its cast.V: 83%

An extremely well done bio-flick, all round to production and casting. I went into it knowing very little about the Beach Boys and came out listening to their music and wanting to know more. I'd consider this a must see for any Beach Boys & Brian Wilson fan, and also for anyone who enjoys a good bio-flick.

Among the best musical biopics I have seen. Loved its unconventional approach to the genre and how it provided a bunch of different perspectives into Brian Wilson's musical genius and personal struggles. Some wonderful performances by Dano, Cusack and Banks too.
My fav movie of 2015.

I didn't know too much about this film going into it and I enjoyed 'Love & Mercy'. This is not just your typical music biopic as it is unique and I'm still not sure how I felt about them casting two different actors in the role. The music is great and Atticus Ross does a great job incorporating The Beach Boys songs into the film and adding his own twist to them at times. But it is Paul Dano who really steals the show here; I've always known him to be a great actor, but he is absolutely great in this. I thought the film did run a little too long and wish they would have shown a little more of Brian Wilson's 70s stage, where he stayed in bed (but not with a 3rd actor). I also felt the ending wrapped things up a little to quickly and wish that would have been a little more fulfilling. Overall a solid film that I wanted to give 4 stars, but I had a few little problems with the film that stuck with me.

Another good movie about the fine line between genius and madness, this one with a story that could have ended like Michael Jackson's but for the love of a good woman. All the actors do a great job and I love the music

It is a very good movie, but I wanted more of the interaction with the band and a more chronologically structured story with the progression of his music spotlighted, but that would be a different movie.

Everything in this movie is a perfect representation of Brian Wilson. Not just in aesthetics (although that was pulled off just as well), but in Wilson's mind, his approach to music and his artistic innovation. The cast and their performances are immaculate, the development of persons living and dead are of such unconventional realism and the score is of such haunt that can only truly reflect the inner workings of Wilson's mind.
Glad I watched this. Wasn't familiar with Brian Wilson's life story at all and amazed that he pulled through. Excellent performances from Paul Dano, Paul Giamatti, Elizabeth Banks, and John Cusack.

maybe i was expecting more, but it is a beautiful movie. even if the cast was on point, im not sure if it was the best script to tell it, the ending was not so great for such a interest and not so known story.
I couldn't buy into John Cusack as Brian Wilson, but great performances by both him as an older B.W. and Paul Dano as a younger B.W.

This film suffices the standard for biographical pictures and carries multiple strong performances, and it really shows Wilson's love for music and the struggles that he went through in his lifetime. Okay, so I knew nothing about this movie going into it, and I barely even knew who The Beach Boys were. For me, this film was as entertaining as I thought it could've been , and although this is a quality made film, I didn't love this film or anything. That doesn't stray from the fact that this was a good movie, just not an outstanding one by any means.I can't write this without saying that the acting performances here were breathtaking. There were multiple stand-out performances here that really made the movie for me. Both Paul Dano and John Cusack did amazing jobs as the role of Brian Wilson, and I truly thought that they gave some of the best performances of the entire year. They both portrayed this character so genuine and so realistically, and I was astounded by their performances. Elizabeth Banks was also great in her role, along with many others who all depicted the characters nicely. I also really loved Paul Giamatti, and these were all performances that will truly be remembered for a long time.Ultimately, the movie flips back and forth between two periods in Brian Wilson's life. I actually liked that aspect of the movie, but one caught my attention more than the other. I really enjoyed when the movie focused up on Brian Wilson's younger life, where he was played by actor Paul Dano. In those moments, we saw Wilson as a young member of The Beach Boys, and he was someone who had an immense passion for music. I loved seeing someone so intimate and passionate about their music, and seeing someone so engaged in their work is inspiring. It was amazing to see how he viewed the world from his point of view, and it was also shocking to see just what he went through. Although the other half of the story was good enough (Wilson as he was older), I wasn't necessarily as hooked as I was in the other moments. Although it's not the main point of the film, it was awe-inspiring to watch this man who had a gift for sounds and art, and it made me admire him a lot more.This movie really is a biographic on the life of Brian Wilson, and with that being said, Brian Wilson (spoiler) suffers from Paranoid Schizophrenia. This is a belief where a person has false delusions that a person(s) is plotting against them, and these delusions can lead to things such as depression. They really took a respectful, yet very real take on this disease, and that was also one of the most interesting parts of the film. They really handled it very well, and there were plenty of moments in this movie where we really saw this disease present itself. It was a really unique story to tell, and one that I would love to learn more about.I also really liked how this movie was shot and filmed. There were certain times where it was shot like a documentary, and that made the film seem so much more real. Everything about this film made it feel very real, and their depiction of the story felt very natural and honest. I can at least credit the film for its realism, and it really does make this film worth watching.In the end, this movie was good. Although I really have no glaring negatives about it, that doesn't neccesarily mean I was head over heals for this film. It's a great film with spectacular acting, superb shots, and a great vision. Although it really was a quality production, I just wasn't hooked throughout the movie. I caught myself dozing off a few times and my mind wandering several others. This is truly is a quality produced film, but its just not one that neccesarily hooked me.

I thought I was a Beach Boys fan but I had no clue all this happened to Brian Wilson. This movie really opened my eyes. I really felt for both Brian Wilson portrayals (Paul Dano, John Cusack). Paul Dano was phenomenal, and the directing was beautifully done as we get to see two different portrayals in one movie. 4.5/5

I have never cared for the Beach Boys or their music, but the movie is a great achievement by Bill Pohlad. Watched it on a plane and it was worth watching. Cusack, Dano and Giamatti are brilliant, and Elizabeth Banks is an angel.

You don't have to be a Beach Boys fan to love this film. In fact this film is about that one special Beach Boy whose name is Brian Wilson, who is perfectly impersonated by two actors. One for the young Brian who was a studio workaholic, a sound perfectionist, the genius who masterminded those unmatched melodies. The other Brian Wilson is a lost person under total control, who fights the daemons of the past. But there is a glimpse of hope for the later, as he gets to meet a very kind woman who quickly understands Brians worries and supports him in her best way. The permanent switch between past and present of Brians's life makes this film even more interesting and catches the curiosity of the spectator. The scenes are of course strengthened by the matching Beach Boys songs.Cusack"s Part is just a bad addition to the film.
One of the best movies of the year

Dano, Cusack, Giamatti and Banks are core performers and handle the script well, and fans get the inside scoop on Wilson's entrapment by a manipulator. But, the elongated paranoid and drug-induced scenes got quite old and made the movie drag a number of times. The editor's razor needed to be a little sharper.

"Love & Mercy" follows young and older Brian Wilson and his band, The Beach Boys. While we flash back and forth between the bands struggles and triumphs, and into the future where he is trying to find love and dealing with Schizophrenia, the film's deep vibes and meaningful visuals made me very emotional. Paul Dano is incredible in his portrayal of Brian Wilson and John Cusack plays his illness very well. Elizabeth Banks really felt like someone who had no idea how to handle this situation. In the end, "Love & Mercy" satisfies with brilliant writing, superb direction, and a story that is much more worth telling than I expected it to. I really loved watching this film and it displays amazing performances all around and celebrates their best music in style. This is not a film you should miss. Definitely worth it's praise.

A very interesting and well-acted biopic on Brian Wilson played by Paul Dano in his younger years and John Cusack in his older years. Cusack doesn't particularly look like Wilson, but his performance as an older Beach Boy fighting demons is captivating. So is Paul Dano. Let's not leave out Elizabeth Banks who plays Wilson's love interest and Paul Giamatti who is scary as Wilson's medical guardian. The music will bring fans back to the glory days of The Beach Boys and new insight to one of its members whose life was anything but sunshine. Grade: A-

It's really well done, especially since it has a rather unique framing device.The film is split in two intertwining halves. In one half, a young Brian Wilson (Paul Dano) struggles to create music for the Beach Boys. In the second half, a now older Brian Wilson (John Cusack) is dealing with a few demons, both physical and mental as a lover (Elizabeth Banks) helps him over come them.Let's take them one half at a time, starting with Dano. He is absolutely incredible as the young Brian Wilson. Watching him struggle with creating news songs has Dano running through many emotions: frustration, the looming sense of failure, disappointing his family (especially since they're his bandmates). Dano nails every single one of them. The scene where he comes up with the melody for Good Vibrations is particularly noteworthy as it's the only time Dano asks someone else to help him write a song. This is absolutely wonderful work.John Cusack doesn't quite reach the same highs as Dano does, but he does do a very respectable job. He makes his portrayal of schizophrenia believable. His romantic scenes with Elizabeth Banks have that right sort of awkward charming you'd expect from someone with a few ants shy of a picnic. This is a good performance by Cusack. He's just not really given as much opportunity to reach the same heights Dano is. Elizabeth Banks is really good, too. She is a bit of the standard "concerned girlfriend/wife", though. The film does leave a question or two unanswered. Dano's descent into his mental issues is well documented, but his drug addiction feels a tad glossed over. It is a little difficult to see how Dano's problems come back to bite Cusack. Mostly because it feels like we went from point A to F while skipping everything in between. However, Cusack's and especially Dano's performances are so good, that they nearly overcome this issue.

There have been plenty of great musician biopics over the years, but I can't remember there being two incredible ones in the same year. Straight Outta Compton and Love & Mercy are two very different films in terms of structure and story for that matter, but both are equally as gripping and satisfying.Focusing mostly solely on Brian Wilson, The Beach Boys leader, Love & Mercy tells the story of Brian in the early days of the band, and also his days in his 40's when his therapist controlled most of his life. The film's structure goes back and forth between these two eras with Paul Dano playing Wilson in his early days and John Cusack later on. Both of the performances exude a great amount of pain and suffering while still feeling relatable at the same time. Bill Pohlad also deserves a lot of credit for his ability to weave the two time periods together in seamless fashion.The music of The Beach Boys will suck you in from the start, but it's really the writing, direction, and performances that keep you watching. The eerie tone is not that of a mainstream film, but that's a good correlation to the not-so-mainstream 'Pet Sounds' album the group worked on for a majority of the early years scenes. The film also does a good job of portraying the crazy genius that Brian Wilson was. His ability to mix song structure and break the norm of music at that time and even stray away from where the group was is unparalleled and extremely risky.Paul Giamatti plays a similar back-stabbing character as he does in Straight Outta Compton, but it fits perfectly for his strengths. Really, there aren't any real weaknesses of this film. It's captivated throughout and the performances may even be worthy of some recognition come awards season. A job well done.+Both lead performances+Strange tone+Bill Pohlad's consistent direction+Who doesn't love the music?8.2/10

'Love and Mercy' is a Biopic that doesn't really focus of the 'Beach Boys' and their music, rather it is a very personal story that explores the life of Brian Wilson from some of the highest points in his life right down to some of the lowest. I knew nothing about the Beach Boys or Brian Wilson except for their biggest hits but man i can't deny that i am really interested to find out more about Brian. This film really goes to places i never thought it would upon hearing about it, it does have its fun light-hearted moments but the majority of this film is really about the personal struggles of Brian Wilson and how he had to overcome these obstacles in his life. The film has an interesting structure, rather than focusing on a specific time in his life and showing how he changed progressively, the film follows a younger Brian played by Paul Dano and a post Beach Boys Brian played by John Cusack. This odd structure of highlighting these two times in his life concurrently throughout the film allowed the writers and director to get creative with the way they represented Brian in both times and how they ultimately depicted his transition without showing what happens in between. On a personal level, and in terms of the way they represented and depicted Brian in these two stages of his life and connected them this film was incredible. But from a storytelling perspective, it was a little off. The two times were shown in a way that made them feel like a series of events in Brian's life rather than a flowing story. The way it switched back and forth with all the jumps in time worked to show off Brian's story and quickly develop his character but as a cohesive start to finish story, especially with the younger Brian, it didn't work as well as i would have liked. As the film progressed, this structure of swapping between the older and younger Brian worked more and more but initially for the first 20 minutes it felt a little choppy and hard to get used to. If i go back now after having more experience with that structure it may work better, but just a minor thing.Oh, the performances in this film were just unbelievable. From Paul Dano and John Cusack playing different versions of Brian, to Elizabeth Banks as Melinda and Paul Giamatti as Eugene Landy they were all incredible, powerful and amazing performances. One of the more fascinating things was how Paul Dano and John Cusack managed to somehow play what are essentially these two different characters in a way that you still saw elements of Brian's younger self in his older self and vice versa. It really was great to see, but seriously already, when is Paul Dano going to get some Oscar recognition? This guy is a fantastic versatile actor, from Prisoners to this he really is shaping up to be an incredible dramatic actor and i only improving over time. Elizabeth Banks also puts in a very very emotionally driven performance and in her limited screen time still made her presence felt. But what may have been the most powerful performance in the film was Paul Giamatti as Eugene Landy. I don't know how this guy does it, he literally transforms into this character and where at first you go 'Hey, thats Paul Giamatti'', by the end of the film you completely forgot it was even him. You can draw many parallels between his character in this film and his role in 'Straight Outta Compton' and that is a really good thing as both performances are ones to remember from this year. Don't worry, even though the main focus on the film is almost exclusively on Brian Williams, you do get to see some of the behind the scenes of making some of the Beach Boys' biggest hits. Their music accompanies the film so well and they really did have a song that fit the tone of the film at all moments throughout. So in the end, if you are a fan of Brian Williams and the Beach Boys and you know the story i am sure you will get a good kick out of the film. If not, i would still recommend you check it out because it gives you very interesting insight into the troubled life of Brian Williams and shows off his character really well supported by great performances. - 7

Breaking away from conventional biopic structure, LOVE & MERCY is a well-crafted and deeply-intriguing examination into the life and mind of a uniquely-talented yet tortured individual. While Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys makes for a strong central character - with Paul Dano giving an off-kilter performance that further solidifies his skill in tackling emotionally-complicated subjects as well as a resurgent turn by John Cusack, Bill Pohlad's directorial debut displays a surprising discipline towards characterization as it never allows the narrative to stray too far, thus providing a film that is insightful and sympathetic yet filled with smooth editing, fun music, and a distinct and very fitting visual palette. Specifically, the scenes of Wilson's recording sessions in the studio with both his band as well as the studio musicians are some of the best moments in the film; they effectively give viewers a glimpse of authenticity and a seemingly exclusive behind-the-scenes access despite it being a re-creation - undoubtedly an impressive execution.

It's much better, and far more moving, than I anticipated. Like most biopics, it does occasionally get bogged down in needless melodrama but unlike most biopics it never gets lost there. The dual narratives focusing on two parts of Wilson's life compliment each other nicely and the small scale focus ensures that "Love & Mercy" never ends up being another montage movie that only focuses on events rather than the characters.
Great movie - outstanding casting, direction, acting, script, cinematography, music. Bravo Paul Dano, John Cusack and Elizabeth Banks.

Though Love & Mercy tries a little to be a little more than a paint-by-numbers troubled musician biopic a la Walk the Line, it still collapses into all the same tropes that make traditional biopics a little insufferable. That said, Love & Mercy has enough interesting moments to make it work a view. The sequences where Paul Dano's Brian Wilson explains the pop masterpieces in his brain to a group of studio musicians and we get to watch Pet Sounds take shape are inspired and captivating. Dano's performance on the whole is outstanding and his career has reached a point where it's like, "Paul Dano's in it? I'm in." The film jumps back and forth between Dano's Pet Sounds Wilson and Cusack's being-held-prisoner-by-a-crazy-doctor Wilson and the latter Wilson segments are where most of the trouble lies. There's nothing wrong with the performances from Cusack, Elizabeth Banks, and Paul Giamatti. Everyone is terrific, but the character building of the latter Wilson is too one dimensional to be compelling. It turns him into a victim and reinforces this general theme of "Brian Wilson was a musical genius and everyone tried holding him back from creating the beautiful music in his troubled brain." He's either misunderstood or a victim the whole time and this clouds any sense of us getting to know who Brian Wilson really is. He's never really on the hook and the movie tries to make a saint out of the man while glossing over his troubles and struggles and putting the blame entirely on Mike Love and Eugene Landy. Although maybe including or even mentioning Wilson's struggles with drug addiction would have just ticked another box on the biopic cliche list, and zooming out, this is still a fascinating story even if it feels like they were trying a little too hard to appease the Brian Wilson camp.

I don't think I've ever seen a biopic quite like LOVE & MERCY before, and I'm still processing what I've seen, to be honest. Focusing on two time periods in Brian Wilson's life, it explores the Beach Boys' heyday in the 1960's (with Paul Dano) and a low period in the 1980's (with John Cusack) during which he meets his second wife, Melinda (Elizabeth Banks), who helps him out of his precarious situation with Eugene Landy (Paul Giamatti), a psychologist who is very controlling of his personal life. Unlike GET ON UP, the James Brown biopic from last year that followed a stream-of-consciousness approach to narrative structure, LOVE & MERCY is very linear. The two timelines do kind of fade into one another, but the end goal of Brian Wilson's rehabilitation is always front and center. The best aspect of the film is dual performance by Paul Dano and John Cusack as Brian Wilson. Although they each play him differently, due to the different circumstances in those periods of Brian Wilson's life, they still felt like the same person. Paul Dano gets the showier performance, but John Cusack still does excellent work as the heavily medicated Wilson of the 1980's. And, both of them accurately portray the loneliness and isolation that Wilson must have felt. The supporting cast do just as good, though. Paul Giamatti was suitably slimy as the Eugene Landy, the psychologist who takes advantage of Brian Wilson in his weak state, and Elizabeth Banks was very charming and grounded as Melinda Ledbetter, the woman who finally rescues Brian from the prison that his life became. From a technical standpoint, LOVE & MERCY is very competent, with occasional flashes of brilliance. One particularly memorable shot was a long take around a recording studio as Brian is instructing two cellists on the sound he wants them to make. There were also a couple similar shots in Brian's Malibu home (in the 1980's period). There was also a few sequences where the footage was degraded to look like it was recorded a long time ago, which I thought was creative. Then, there's the music. It's been a long time since I've actually listened to the Beach Boys, but it was refreshing to hear it. The score by Atticus Ross was also quite good, its sparseness capturing, again, the loneliness and isolation in Brian Wilson's head. If there's anything negative I have to say, it's that there are some sporadic pacing issues, but nothing so egregious as to make the film unwatchable. Besides, the ending was rather satisfying anyway. Overall, LOVE & MERCY was a uniquely structured psychological portrait in lieu of the typical biography, and it should be commended for that, in addition to the excellent performances and music. As to whether or not he was a genius or madman, I guess it's a little of both (but mostly genius, in my opinion).

Love & Mercy is a very good portrait of musical genius, Brian Wilson, at two pivotal moments in his life. Eschewing the comprehensive life's story approach that most biopics use, Bill Pohlad decided to focus on the periods surrounding the making of the 'Pet Sounds' album and how he met his current wife, subsequently purging a very toxic individual from his life (ex-manager Eugene Landy). This is a nice change of pace for the tired old musical biopic genre.Paul Dano is great as young Brian Wilson. He portrays Wilson as a tortured, but brilliant puppy dog of a man that he was with heart and sincerity. John Cusack on the other hand is quite simply serviceable as elder, nearly zombified Brian Wilson. Paul Giamatti and Elizabeth Banks are good in their supporting roles.

As a huge Brian Wilson/Beach Boys fan, I'm a bit biased. But this is a truly original, heartfelt biopic not just about one of music's greatest tortured geniuses, but about the prison of mental illness and the freedom that comes from an empathetic heart.

"You need to get back to yourself".I'm on board with any music related biopic, regardless of decade, genre of music or whether or not I even like the artists group. It's usually a fascinating story showing the tortured soul of the musicians rise to fame - through managers, family problems and any other number of things. Occasionally the whole tortured soul thing is a gimmick used to amplify things for the audience. Yep, you guessed it the story of 'Brian Wilson' (Paul Dano/ John Cusack) (assuming this is 100% true) genuinely applies to the tortured soul motif.However, I do now feel full of cringe feelings for using that phrase. My knowledge of 'The Beach Boys', 'Brian Wilson' and even this film are next to none. Iv'e heard of all three - the music and a trailer for the movie. I didn't even now it specifically about 'Brian Wilson' so my ignorance was in full force go into it. There are glimpses of childhood but it doesn't start there. Opting instead to start in the 1980s where 'Brian' first meets 'Melinda' (Elizabeth Banks) a car saleswomen who he takes a shine to. It's oddly paced particularly in the beginning with it almost literally switching between 1980s and height of 'Beach Boys' fame in the 1960s every 5 minutes. It gets a little difficult to get a gripe of things at the start but things eventually spread out. It has a nice balance of the two eras and neither really stand out from one or other.Both 'Dano' and 'Cusack' do well enough and when it gets to the severe state 'Brian' was in (in both 60s and 80s) it can be quite startling. But doesn't go far enough, the reveal of what 'Eugene Landy' (Paul Giamatti playing another nice at first guy) is doing is horrible but the film doesn't give it much weight - or show it for how severe it is. It's more of a "oh wow" than a horrified gasp. For all the excellent casting and performances (Dano and Cusack are wonderful) aside when something like that severity crops up or when 'Brian' starts to fall apart it all feels a little, understated.The use of the bands music throughout is one of the smartest Iv'e seen used. Holding back the urge to use them at every and any interval. It's intertwined in Brian's battle with his own psyche with swirling music cues from their various songs all-together. That's the films narrative strength - almost beautifully - showcasing Brian's inner thoughts and eventually battle with schizophrenia.The plaudits should rightfully go to the acting of both 'Cusack' and 'Dano' because in the end it's all just decent. The story is decent but lacks the punch it needs in emotionally charged scenes. All the way through I was interested without being totally engaged, I constantly felt disappointed and I'm not sure why. There's nothing bad here, it's all just very inoffensive.

Love and Mercy is a biopic about Brian Wilson the, arguably, most well known member of the Beach Boys. It takes place at two different time periods in Wilson's life, the first is of a young Wilson (Paul Dano) as he creates the album Pet Sounds and the hit single Good Vibrations. The second takes place in the mid eighties after the fame has begun to wear off and Brian Wilson (John Cusack) is now a broken shell of himself and shows him falling in love with Melinda Ledbetter (Elizabeth Banks). Both time periods also show Wilson's struggle with mental health.Things I Liked:Paul Dano. Dano plays the 60's Wilson. He has a youth and ambition to him that really works well. Dano has a knack for playing tortured characters and he shines through at times being able to showcase a number of believable dualities of his personality including: profound and childlike, driven and hesitant, commanding and walked over. Dano shows the early moments in Wilson's mental decline and he really shows it well over the course of the movie.Elizabeth Banks. Banks plays Melinda Ledbetter, the older Wilson's love interest, and eventual wife. Banks brings a strong and compelling characterization to Ledbetter and it's a very different role than we usually see from Banks and it was a nice reminder that she is a skilled actress beyond the world of hokey comedies.The Soundtrack. I mean how could you not make a movie about the Beach Boys and not have a good soundtrack. The movie plays a wide variety of hits from Wilson's career and all of the Beach Boys' classic songs make an appearance including, Surfin' U.S.A., Good Vibrations, Wouldn't It Be Nice, and so many more. The soundtrack plays an interesting parallel to Wilson's life and his state of mind throughout the movie.Things I Didn't Like:John Cusack. John Cusack gives a decent performance as the older Wilson, but one I feel is unneeded. Paul Dano gives such a compelling performance that I was much more interested in the younger Wilson and wished that they has simply let Dano play the part in both times through aging makeup and other effects. Cusack is fine but forgettable next to his younger counterpart.Paul Giamatti. Giamatti is apparently working hard playing every single douchebag manager in every music biopic ever. And it's getting a little tired, stale, forgettable, and cartoony at times. This one is especially so. He is an overly-belligerent short fused hot head at times, he plays a sort of action movie manipulator at others, twisting and beating Wilson's psyche throughout the film.Overall. Overall, the movie is a success. It's an interesting an compelling story. The dual plot lines make for neat parallels and the performances are mostly strong. Dano outshines Cusack and makes you wonder why they chose to split to role in half. Banks shows her dramatic chops and reminds you that she is a skilled actress. Giamatti is the only major role in the film that feels over the top and out of place. But the story succeeds and the soundtrack that accompanies the film is a fantastic wave of nostalgia that works through the cracks to tie the entire thing together. A very enjoyable film.
Great Movie Really enjoyed it

So when watching any biopic about a musician of any kind I just instantly compare to the run of flicks over the years including Walk the Line, Ray, Amadeus etc. Now we have Love & Mercy, and this one takes a different approach then all those other movies. Most of the time you get the story from young to old. Kid is young, discovers music, something bad happens, leaves home, gets famous, parties too much, hits rock bottom and then learns the lesson. What is good about Love & Mercy, in it's exploration of The Beach Boys lead Brian Wilson, is it tells his story but from the point of two short sections of his life. You get a brief look at The Beach Boys rising up and then the movie comes in showing you younger Wilson as he wants to expand his music into something more then just pop surfing hits, and older Wilson dealing with voices in his head and over-medication. Both Wilson's are portrayed quite well by Paul Dano and John Cusack and the rest of the cast is top notch. The writing, the way this film is shot is all done quite well and the movie is at it's best when young Wilson is in the studio creating music. This isn't a feel good story at all, and that took away from my enjoyment of it, and learning that Wilson isn't a fan of his earlier work is a bit of a downer for me as well. Where I didn't like the direction is that Wilson comes off very sympathetically in the movie, as in he's a misunderstood genius and that he's dealing with health problems and he deserves plenty of sympathy. However, Wilson didn't start hearing voices in his head by his own admission (not portrayed in the film) until after he took LSD. He was a heavy drug user and there isn't much accountability of that usage in the film. If you are looking for a history of The Beach Boys, this isn't your movie at all. What it is thought is a movie about another musician who struggles to keep up with his own success and dealing with a troubling past that would make us all go a little nuts. If you know going in what type of movie this is, I think it makes it a better watch.

Two thousand fifteen is proving to be a solid year for musician biopics and documentaries, what with "Amy," "Montage of Heck," "Straight Outta Compton," and the upcoming "I Saw the Light." But, "Love & Mercy," to date, is my favorite one this year. Starring John Cusack and Paul Dano both as Brian Wilson, in different stages of his life, "Love & Mercy" shows how someone as creative, imaginative, and successful as founding Beach Boy Brian Wilson can fall from the top of the pops to the bottom of the abyss. Paul Dano shows the cheerful, younger side of Wilson, back when the Beach Boys were crafting some of the best pop music known to man- his transformation for the role involve weight gains and singing lessons with the man itself, so it goes to show how deserving he is for some attention from the Academy. He shows Wilson soaring high, but finds him collapsing into himself just a few short years after his fame: and Dano captures this perfectly. Cusack plays a more subdued Wilson, after he's regained some composure, but after he's fallen under the spell of Eugene Landy (played by Giamatti). The tragic rise and fall and rise again of Brian Wilson is played out beautifully, soundtracked to some of the best music ever made, and it shows so much humanity in such a brief window. Easily one of the best films of 2015.

The hard-hitting story of The Beach Boys' Brian Wilson, Love & Mercy is easily the strongest musical biopic in recent memory, thanks to impactful performances from Paul Dano and John Cusack, strong direction (featuring gorgeous cinematography and stunning sound mixing), and a tight screenplay.

The bio flick "Love & Mercy" tells the tale of the professional and personal life of Brian Wilson, one of the key members of the infamous Beach Boys band. OK, so let's do the math here, I do include an enormous amount of puns in my movie reviews, and I am reviewing a movie about a Beach Boys member. So you know what that means, will have "puns, puns, puns" til my readers start to run away!!! Anyways, Wilson's challenging dilemma was no laughing matter. He battled schizophrenia throughout most of his adult life. Director Bill Pohlad marveled in presenting a double-sided chronology to Wilson's story; first as a young successful songwriter/producer/member of the Beach Boys who thought that "wouldn't it be nice" for the band to transform into a more avant- garde sound which dismayed his Wilson brother bandmates, but most notably his cousin bandmate Mike Love. Paul Dano's performance as the younger Dano was right on key. On the flip side, John Cusack magnificently plays the older Wilson who was already diagnosed with full-fledged schizophrenia and is profoundly controlled by his psychiatrist Dr. Eugene Landy. When the older Wilson meets Melinda Ledbetter, a former model turned car saleswoman, it simply leads to better times for the mentally ailing Wilson; but not without a control fight from Team Landy; let's just say Dr. Landy was a real kokomierda. "Love & Mercy" is an excellent piece, but not a perfect film; the screenplay at times was bit disoriented and repetitious. But from the instant, I picked up "good vibrations" from the supersonic performances from John Cusack and Paul Dano as the Brians, and ledbeter not forget Elizabeth Banks rousing work as Melinda. "God only knows" how people can take so many puns in movie reviews, but "don't worry baby" because I'm just about done here. "Love & Mercy" is worth riding its cinematic wave; in other words, it's beaching, I mean bitching! ***** Excellent

At the helm of this unique biopic is Paul Dano, who deserves a round of applause for his role as singer/songwriter/musician and co-founder of the Beach Boys, Brian Wilson. Dano excels in the film at playing against type and turning in an awe-inspiring, stellar and heart-breaking performance as Brian Wilson in the hay day of the Beach Boys just before they released the equally against type Pet Sounds album. Above all, Dano owns the movie with his charismatic, sweet-natured and quirky take on a troubled musical icon. Fast-forwarding around twenty years later in the late 1980s, Dano steps out and lets the impeccable John Cusack step in, who plays the man with a distantly dreamy and crushing desperation for something to hold onto, with his mind now much more faded and having become a child stuck in an unwilling man's body. Luckily, Wilson finds an anchor in his newfound love, Melinda Ledbetter, played with a seeming ease and motherly quality by Elizabeth Banks. However, the dividing factor between them comes in the form of Dr. Eugene Landy, the maniacal, insatiable tormenter of the broken shell that is still only just Brian Wilson. Paul Giamatti, who plays Landy, is remarkable and many times overwhelming in every second he is on screen, taking advantage of every moment to convey the doctor's deranged obsession with Wilson's every move and the move of every one that tries to stop him. Some of the best scenes are in the studio during the creation of the quintessential songs in Pet Sounds, involving the viewer with the music through the breaking down and assembling of each sound and rhythmic beat. The studio is also the room where much of the 1960s Brian Wilson seems to slip ever closer towards the madness we know he did slip into, but meanwhile the music is phenomenal and truly gives off good vibrations.

Very creative soundtrack, Pity Paul Dano having to replicate that voice! It's a well done movie, colourful, believable, great characters; I would have loved to see it as a mini series showing more of Wilson's life. What about his tape machine interviews with the studio? Anyway, a good intro to his creative genius, a very watchable and entertaining biopic.

Paul Dano and Elizabeth Banks are both a joy to watch and isn't it nice to see DTV-Cusack doing something understating and more befitting his acting abilities?

Fascinating, tragic and inspiring; Love & Mercy explores the emotionally turbulent and musically brilliant times of Brian Wilson, co-founder and lead singer of the Beach Boys. Bill Pohlad's absorbing drama is unique from the traditional biopic concentrating on the underlying drama behind the music, rather than the music itself.Brilliantly depicting a complex, creative and highly tortured man obsessed with pushing the boundaries of his talents whilst trying to survive against mounting pressure, the story cuts between key moments in two time windows of the singer/ songwriters life from the late 60s and 80s, both marvellously portrayed respectively by Paul Dano and John Cusack.Rightly perceived as breezy through there wholesome, carefree, toe-tapping sound, this film bypasses the California Girls image of surf and sun, bikini ladies into the major conflicts with his band as he endeavours to make the greatest album ever through some unconventional methods.It also brings light to the physical and mental abuse Wilson received at the hands of his record producer father (Bill Camp), Wilson's struggles with voices in his head and subsequent questionable medical care of Dr Eugene Landy (Paul Giamatti) as a self-appointed gate keeper.Occasionally jarring and long winded in its editing, this movie shines through the stunning strength of its actors performances. There is charming chemistry between Cusack and an empathetic Cadillac dealer Melinda Ledbetter (Elizabeth Banks) who becomes Wilson's saviour (and future wife).The Verdict: More interesting the well-executed, switch from major to minor key in seconds.Published: Canberra Weekly MagazineDate of Publication: 16/07/2015

Love and Mercy focuses on the Beach Boys' Brian Wilson's descent into self-imposed exile caused by a lethal combination of pre-existing mental illness and drug use, though Wilson's self-medication is heavily censored in this version of events. As the creative genius at the centre of the Beach Boys Brian Wilson's story is an intriguing one, but Love and Mercy is a slightly jarring experience mainly due to its use of two different actors to play the younger Wilson (Dano) and older Wilson (Cusack). Both handle their parts superbly, especially Dano, but this feels like two separate movies inter-spliced. The circumstances surrounding Brian's split from the Beach Boys and his drift into the manipulative hands of Dr Landy are not fully explained, but the scenes involving the creation of Pet Sounds are done so superbly they are worth the price of admission alone.

This was a good movie, but I had high expectations and the film failed to meet them. There were a few reasons for this.1. This was essentially 3 movies in one -- a movie about a young Brian Wilson, at the top of his game; a movie about an older Brian Wilson, a sad shell of his former self; and a documentary on Pet Sounds. It's very hard to put together 3 good movies in a single film.2. Because there was so much to cover, there was little time for character development and most characters came across as boring and one-dimensional. Mike Love was an annoying, difficult obstacle to Wilson's creative genius; Ledbetter was a purely saintly figure; Landy was entirely evil. Characters are more interesting when we understand their motivations and see things from their side. But this movie was mostly caricatures, not characters.3. John Cusack was a poor casting choice. He looked like he was playing John Cusack, not Brian Wilson.4. Hopping back and forth between the 1960s and 1980s didn't work for me. I would have preferred that the pre-credit sequence simply show us a "flash forward" to Brian Wilson in his 1980s, incapacitated state, so that the viewer knows where the film is going. After that, the movie could have focused solely on the young Wilson until the point of his post-Pet Sounds breakdown, then say "20 years later."This was still a fun movie to watch, and the Pet Sounds studio sequences were worth the price of admission alone.
Loved it! It captured the era and the genius of Brian! Kudos for using all the REAL stuff!!

The narrative structure is disjointed, which for me rather detracted from the film, but worth your attention if you like Pet Sounds.

Love and Mercy was a well made, dynamic film about the great Brian Wilson. Just as The Beach Boys songs could evoke both the highs of love and the depths of sadness, so did the movie.Everyone did their roles justice. Paul Dano and John Cusack showed the challenges of "invisible illness" such as overwhelm with both conviction and an appropriate subtlety. Elizabeth Banks was admirable and heartwarming in her role as both his love and protector. Paul Giamatti as Dr. Eugene Landy gives a chillingly convincing performance.All in all, Love and Mercy makes you appreciate the man behind the music even more.

This is a brilliantly crafted movie as we dive into the life of Beach Boys mastermind Brian Wilson who had gone from singer and brilliant songwriter to deep paranoia and depression. Both Paul Dano and John Cusack did a stellar job portraying the character during different periods of his life and well supported by the rest of the cast most importantly Elizabeth Banks who played his current wife Melinda who saved him from sure obliteration and Paul Giamatti who played the doctor Eugene who was keeping him supressed. If you enjoy biopics, The Beach Boys or good cinema in general this is the film to watch
Unlike any biopic I've ever seen, in the best possible way
Quality music biopic about Brian Wilson with outstanding action and direction, You wont regret watching the movie even if you son't listen him.

The storyline with Wilson as a young man is terrific. The scenes of them recording are fantastic depictions of capturing the creative process. But the stuff with Brian Wilson as an adult didn't do much for me.
What an amazing story about one of the greatest artists of all-time!!
Excellent, unusual biopic - not your usual "Behind the Music." Beautiful acting from Paul Dano, John Cusack, Elizabeth Banks and Paul Giamatti.

Knowing literally nothing about the Beach boys and Wilson himself made this a really interesting film. The film is about Brian Wilsons life and is played in the 60's by Dano and the 80's by Cussack. It works well and the best performance bar none was Banks as Wilsons girlfriend in the 80's and future wife. The interesting bit of his life where it was controlled by his doctor was excellent and overall this is worth a watch

Really great biopic. Paul Dano as the younger Brian is fantastic. With access to the Beach Boy audio archives the whole sixties era studio scenes feel incredibly authentic. The surround sound design for the movie is wonderful too.

One cannot recapture the early sixties. There is a scene in the biopic about Brian Wilson going back to see his old home in Hawthorne. A freeway runs through it. To call a man a genius is to suggest he does it all alone. It's a very American idea. Brian Wilson is not a genius. He's a pretty good composer, piano player, bass player and singer. This bio- pic starts to de-rail when it idolizes him for genius; after awhile Brian starts to believe it. There is a scene where the wrecking crew ( studio musicians) hail him--through studio drummer Hal Blaine--that he's the greatest. Of course, they get paid by the hour and the longer they're in studio the more they make. His addictive personality betrays him, and it's difficult for him to go outside his comfort zone. His recovery is encouraging.
Paul Dano is so so good as a young Brian Wilson. This film was just so good. I loved it. Definitely one of 2015's best so far.

If you love music and care about artists this movie will break your heart. Paul Dano played the young Brian Wilson and John Cusack the older. It doesn't matter that they don't look at all alike because they both inhabit their characters so well. Caught between an abusive controlling father and an abusive controlling 'minder', the tortured genius breaks out of the constraints of the art form and creates music that is genuinely new and fresh. Elizabeth Banks portrays the woman who rescues the older Brian from the monster that has him trapped (played chillingly by Paul Giammati). Her character showcases the power that women have to heal broken men and bring them back to their best selves through tenderness and courage. The moment she stares down Giamatti's crazed minder and completely disempowers him is astonishing. Then of course there's the music. The early Beach Boys material is nicely captured in an early montage (with cleverly constructed period effects) so that the bulk of the film can concentrate on the recording of Brian's masterpiece Pet Sounds. To see these great songs constructed layer by layer is a real treat for those who know and love the album. Those who don't will want to download it immediately. The final credit sequence gives us the real Brian Wilson with a live performance of his late period song 'Love and Mercy.' 'Love and mercy that's what we need right now.' Yes indeed. Brian received both and gave the world through his music so much love and joy. This film (unlike some more formulaic biopics) is a genuine honouring of his legacy.
Any fan of the Beach Boys should see this movie! John Cusack and Paul Dano both deliver riveting performances as Brian Wilson.

It's hard to make biopics. Only recently have major films managed to hit the mark. Selma and Lincoln hit the sweet spot by only focusing on one major part of their subject's life (the march of Selma and the 13th amendment respectively). Yes, other films have managed to cover up more time of their subject's life and have managed to be successful (Milk and Walk the Line are examples), but it's harder to do and therefore more unadvisable. Love & Mercy, a biopic on Brian Williams, member of the Beach Boys, tries to go the harder route and almost makes it. Love & Mercy takes place at two different times of Brian William's life. One is when he and the Beach Boys are rising to fame in the 60s (here he is played by Paul Dano), and the other is in the 80s where we see him broken down and on the verge of insanity (there he is played by John Cussack). In the 60s we see Brian and his genius spurn out tunes for such memorable songs like "Good Vibrations" and "God Only Knows" but we see fame get into his head and his work soon takes over him; he begins to hear voices in his head, becomes overweight, and starts fighting with the other band members. Fast-forward to the 80s we see Brian Williams meet a car saleswoman named Miranda (Elizabeth Banks) and they begin to date. Through Miranda's perspective we see how Brian is at a physical, economical, and psychological low; because of this Brian's Dr. (a maniacal Paul Giamatti) takes advantage of him and abuses Brian to his benefit. The film is great in all aspects except one: John Cussack. Cussack is a great actor and he does a fine job in this film, but the problem is that he becomes to focused on his own acting. Yes he portrays Brian's senseless torment with the most curtailed of details like finger twitching, but with this egotistic focus he completely breaks apart from the rest of the cast. This makes all of his interactions with Elizabeth Banks seem non-credible and downright boring. Banks tries her best to fix the divide, but Cussack is too stubborn. Also Dano's performance and Cussack's performance are completely different which makes me see two completely different people in every aspect, they weren't both Brian Williams, and this lack of coordination was on the verge of being fatal for this film, after all Cussack's scenes were half of the film. Fortunately the other half of the film was handled expertly. Paul Dano once again show's that he is worth more than a simple supporting actor (he first surprised me in There Will Be Blood). Dano perfectly transitions his Brian from eager to mad in a way that makes us feel sentient for him as well. Essentially Dano accomplishes the whole point of the film, which is to glorify Brian for the artist that he is. Because of Cussack's solitary performance half the film is slow and boring, but Dano and his portion manage to make the whole film worthwhile.
A well acted movie. Dano is terrific as the younger Wilson. John Cusack is miscast as the '80's version of Wilson. He's good he's just not believeable. All told I would recommend it.

The performances in this movie combined with a non-linear story line that's shown in a way that places you into the heart and soul of one of the most musically brilliant minds of all-time. Beach Boys albums set to repeat for the next month.

Love & MercyIn theatresRating: PG 13 121 minutes BiographyDirector: Bill PolhadWriters: Oren Moverman and Michael A. LernerStarring: John Cusack (the Indie Kings of the 1980s - we loved him in "Say Anything"), Paul Dano (known for "There Will Be Blood" for which he received a BAFTA nomination and for "Little Miss Sunshine") and Elizabeth Banks (the two time Emmy nominee of "30 Rock" and actress in the Hungry Games series). Dano plays the younger Brian Wilson, while John Cusack plays the older version.Everyone knows the Beach Boys and everyone knows who Brian Wilson is. He was the icon of the 1960s. He was much loved and had the albums to prove it. He was a "genius" with music. But his father was hard on him and abusive. Brian needed a break from touring and wanted to record an album, (the now-legendary "Pet Sounds"). It was a flop. That's when Brian began heading voices.The movie is told through flackbacks. Now, his in 40s (Cusack) was been manipulated by Dr. Eugene Landy, his psychiatrist who is played by Paul Giamatti. Brian is cut off from is family, and his only source of companionship is a female car salesperson from whom he bought a Cadillac.Not much comedy to break up the misery. And, the love story fell a bit flat. Or maybe she felt sorry for him? Pohlad is known for his producing ("12 Years a Slave," "Into the Wild" and "Brokeback Mountain") with two stints as a director. Moverman has written 11 script, and received an Oscar nomination for "The Messenger".

It is 1966. While returning from a successful tour, Brian Wilson(Paul Dano) of the Beach Boys suffers a debilitating anxiety attack on the flight home. So, he opts out of the Japan leg of the tour in favor of recording some new music for the band. Now all he has to do is figure out how to get the horse inside of the recording studio.It is 1985. Brian Wilson(John Cusack) would like to buy a car. And not just any car, mind you. Which Melinda Ledbetter(Elizabeth Banks), a salesperson, would like to help him with. That happens under the very watchful eye of Dr. Eugene Landy(Paul Giamatti)."Love and Mercy" is a thoughtful movie about the intersection between madness and genius which also takes the time to redeem the critical reputation of the Beach Boys. The story is set over two time periods which are linked by two surprisingly matching performances from Paul Dano and John Cusack.(Dano plays Brian struggling to communicate while Cusack is the empty husk of what is left.) While each time period is clearly demarcated by its respective fashions, they are joined in one mindbending segment late in the film. The problems arise in how the movie plays out, namely in seeking as pat a resolution as humanly possible for mental illness for which there is no real cure. And I never quite grasped the importance of the will in all of this.

Set to please cinephiles and music lovers alike, Love & Mercy truly is a collective effort of great beauty and touching, raw filmmaking. From a layered, complex and surprisingly gut-wrenching script by Oren Moverman and Michael A. Lerner, Bill Pohlad deconstructs a subjective, fragmented and equally intricate vision of one of the most gifted artists in music history. The film - doted with a surprising high-degree of artistry and narrative sophistication - is graced by a fundamental kindness that strongly enhances the beauty and soul-crushing performances by Dano, Cusack, Banks and Giamatti - all names to remember come award season. In addition - and because this is a film with strong sound roots - one could hardly let the phenomenal work by the sound department go by unnoticed, which, in addition to Atticus Ross' score, underlines the already staggering and groundbreaking sonority of The Beach Boys. Supporting the sporadic eargasm is Robert Yeoman's lyrical execution behind the camera, binding together two periods in time and two lives in constant turmoil, that eventually come together in beautifully cathartic fashion to quiet a soul and harmonize a genius. Love & Mercy justifies its title, living off pure vibrations that weren't made for these times, or any times for that matter, for its protagonist still continues to transcend time.

Biopics can be tricky. Often they try to cover too much ground and feel thin in the process. Thankfully this fine film does the job nicely. Even though it covers a fair bit of ground it nails it in most scenes.
