It's a startling look into the musical genius and troubled life of Brian Wilson, a man who wrote some of the most popular songs of all times. It interchanges, with great skill, two stages of Wilson's life. The Pet Sounds era of the 60s and the broken man of the 80s. We see the music take shape and we see the genesis of his troubled life. It's well written and very engaging and the performances are truly first class. Dano and Cusack play the two Brians and both are great but Paul Giamatti almost steals the the show as the svengali Dr Landy.
Loved this! Great acting by all. Paul Giamatti is particularly menacing!

One of the best "rock" movies I have seen. I really didn't know Brian Wilson's story and John Cusack (ony of my favorites) was terrific although not looking on bit like Wilson. And of course.. . the wonderful songs!

The movie brings back a lot of memories from the mid-60s. Most of my LP album purchases in those days were The Beach Boys. Poor old Brian Wilson was pretty messed up in spite of being a musical genius and pioneer (good role for John Cusack). Paul Giamatti always plays weird characters and his portrayal of Jean is no exception (Jean is actually a very scary person and Paul plays him well). I was expecting a little more music in the film but I liked the movie (now, if I can just find my old albums, even though I don't have an operational turntable anymore, I do want to look at the covers again).

Dano's performance makes real the era and the raggedy tragedy of Wilson's art and life. I especially liked the scenes in the studio. Watching somebody make art in the movies is typically a hot mess, but here, we see a process, made coherent because we know where it's going. I'm less enamored of the Cusack segments, bringing the story into the 90s when he is rescued from a Svengali huckster psychologist, not only because Cusack's look is so different, but because there was so much missing between the different slices of Wilson's life that the latter felt contrived and conflated. Which it is, if you read Wilson's bio. Oh well, it's not perfect, but the music is, and the scenes where the music is central are just so wonderful for this nostalgic geezer who lived through it all. I used to go to the Beach Boys concert every Christmas. Until, of course, the Beetles.

Much of the credit for the artistic merits of "Love & Mercy," the new biopic about Brian Wilson, co-founder of the Beach Boys, goes to screenwriters Oren Moverman ("I'm Not There") and Michael A. Lerner ("August. Eighth"). Together, they have fashioned a story that ping-pongs back and forth between Wilson's early heyday as the brilliant creative force behind the Beach Boys' success - and his subsequent mental unraveling - and the dark period of the 1980s when he languished under the autocratic care of his guru-like psychologist, Eugene Landy. The result is a masterful portrait of a troubled genius, the tolls of fame, and the virtues of perseverance and love.The film (which takes its title from a 1988 song by its subject) is as much a portrait of the creative process as it is of Brian Wilson. We learn plenty about the Beach Boys and about Wilson's private life, but some of the great joys of the movie are the scenes in the music studio. In particular, we see how both "God Only Knows" and "Good Vibrations" were recorded - or, at least, how the screenwriters and director imagine they were made - and the sequences reveal how much of an innovator Brian Wilson was, in spite of his growing problems with mental illness. We need to understand the genius in order to mourn his loss (and hope for his recovery).Much credit should also go to director Bill Pohlad and his cast. This is only Pohlad's second feature film as director: his first, "Old Explorers," was 25 years ago. Since then, Pohlad has worked primarily as a producer, including on "The Tree of Life"; he shared in that film's Best Picture nomination. Here, he has assembled a first-rate group of actors, and made the vital decision to cast two different actors as Wilson, both of them up to the task: Paul Dano ("There Will Be Blood"), as the younger, 1960s Wilson, and John Cusack ("The Paperboy") as the older, 1980s Wilson. Given that Dano is in his early thirties, it's legitimate to wonder why he couldn't have also played the older Wilson, with added makeup. But therein lies part of the brilliance of the film. Casting two such different actors to play the same character at different stages of his life - the one before a major physical and mental cataclysm, the one after - helps to underline that character's significant transformation, and the obstacles in his way as he tries to recover. Cusack has further stated, in a recent interview, how even though he and Dano studied Wilson's life with a similar intensity, neither consulted with the other to make the two performances match in any way. They end up both delivering fully committed portrayals of the same man at vastly different times in his life, and it works perfectly.The rest of the cast is quite strong, as well. Elizabeth Banks ("Pitch Perfect 2"), as Melinda Ledbetter, the woman who helps Wilson in his struggles to free himself from Landy, is a marvel of warmth and restraint. Paul Giamatti ("Sideways"), as Landy, has the difficult task of playing the villain, but he succeeds in making him three-dimensional, if not sympathetic (which the film doesn't intend him to be). If their final duel is as scary and cathartic as it ultimately is, it's due to the power of these two actors in these roles. It's too bad that not all of the other actors - in particular, the rest of the Beach Boys - are as strong, but at least - with Dano, Cusack, Banks and Giamatti - we have a formidable foursome.What surprised me most as I watched the film - and made me fall in love with it - was how unconventional it was in its approach to the material. Because we are dealing with a man - Wilson - who suffers from both severe hearing loss in one ear and auditory hallucinations - the soundtrack quite often reveals completely unexpected noises, or sometimes drops out entirely. In fact, the opening of the film almost feels like there's a problem with the projector (be patient), because we start on Dano at the piano, in distress, then cut to black, then land on Cusack, and then slowly begin to discern other sounds as the credits begin. Though the movie settles down, for a while, to tell enough of a story for us to gather salient facts about Wilson in both the 1960s and 1980s, it returns, time and again, to these experimental techniques, reminding us that art - like Wilson - when made with purpose, can seem as it if knows no boundaries. This is a movie with a definite method to its madness.
Great movie. Made you think. Superbly performed.
Excellent movie a must see
As musical-genius-biopics go, this one is pretty amazing.
painful to watch. If you like spending 2 hours with a mentally ill person then this is the movie for you
Great film. Will host on movie night here, sometime this summer.

Saw LOVE & MERCY today, an intelligent film about two periods of Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys life. There's a vivid half with Paul Dano (excellent performance from this slow rhythm actor) and a well cast band tracing hois most creative period and the decent to paranoia. The second part is the sad story of Wilson in the 80's, manipulated by a quack doctor and finding love and perhaps rescue from a car saleswoman (Elizabeth Banks). Both parts are interesting stories, but the earlier story is more fun to watch. John Cusack does a sensitive job as the older Wilson--but he doesn't look like Wilson or Paul Dano, so that may throw you. The scenes in the music studios are the best part of the film--you feel the positive, creative energy--the Good Vibrations, I guess!

Paul Dano's performance of Brian Wilson is the one you'll likely remember more, as he is allowed to more wholly inhabit both the insecurities as well as the ingenuity of Brian Wilson (circa 1960s). While likely just as demanding, John Cusack's role of the late 1980s Brian Wilson doesn't come off as resounding as Dano's, due in large part to the narrow scope of Wilson's character by this point in time (as he was psychologically and physiologically manipulated by Dr. Gene Landy).

Paul Dano totally captures Brian Wilson. John Cusack captures a very disturbed but sweet man. Ostensibly they are both playing Wilson, though you'd never really know it. We learn a bit of the truth about Wilson but LOVE AND MERCY is too full of music and entertainment industry cliches to have any impact. And then the fantastical sequences are too sloppy to work in any way. But there is one major standout--Elizabeth Banks who is simply translucent while being totally grounded. Really cool.

LOve & Mercy flips back and forth between the mid 60s and mid-80s to contrast two parts of Brian Wilson's life and collapse.It suffers from too much of the 60s stuff looking like an episode of The Monkees and it looks as if a lot fo explanatory scenes were left in the editing room as characters come and go without explanation, some rather important.The 80s sections are completely taken over by Paul Giametti as the villainous psychiatrist who takes control of Wilson's life and money.Good but not quite great, and Heroes & Villains might have been a better title.

As a lifelong fan of Brian Wilson's music I thought this was a beautifully conceived and very well executed way of telling some key parts of his story. The looming presence of Murray Wilson, the cynical antics of Eugene Landy and Mike Love's negative impact (which continue to this day) were captured convincingly. One question mark over Elizabeth Banks' Melinda Ledbetter: was she really that saintly? Either way a wonderful film

Hollywood at its best, with first class production values. But from the first set of chords that Dano's Wilson picks out on the piano, that you think are leading you one place, then with their complexity take you by surprise, to Cusack's beautiful serenade to Melinda, to the brilliant studio sessions, this film is a true education in the art of musicianship. In a masterpiece of editing, each scene of a song being worked in the studio is like a song in itself. If you find the rhythm of the first musical segment, and keep following it through the pause that follows while it's being discussed, you will pick it up again exactly in the next bit, and this continues for the length of the scene. Brian Wilson's art is deservedly paid the highest of compliments by the musicians. The entire cast is excellent. Elizabeth Banks as the lovely Melinda turns up in full American regalia - big hair, lots of makeup, sparkling smile, tons of glamour; be not distracted, because her Melinda has an unshakeable sense of self, intelligence and understanding, and she inspires complete confidence in the people whom she needs, to help to turn Wilson's life around. Someone remarks to Wilson, 'who do you think you are, Mozart?' to which Dano responds with perfect understatement. Dano's portrayal of Wilson's singing is also brilliant. If you never listened closely to the Beach Boys, as I hadn't, do so now. Rarely does Hollywood produce a film with this sense of reality, combined with complex technical content of real interest, true compassion, and sheer beauty of characterisation. The ending is wonderful.

Biopics typically tread similar waters. Filmmakers who dabble in the true-life stories of renowned geniuses offer exceptional depictions of such people, yet they all follow the same tired formula. 'Love & Mercy' is anything but a typical biopic. Its single greatest strength is its unconventionality. Rather than paint its subject simply as a damaged genius, the film humanizes him a great deal and makes viewers feel like they're sitting next to the musical legend, offering them the most unique window into the psyche of any biographical subject depicted on the screen. However, like other biopics before it, 'Love & Mercy' is only as good as its cast, and this one is nothing short of phenomenal. John Cusack displays some great work as the older Brian Wilson, but it is Paul Dano who absolutely nails it as the younger Brian Wilson. His best scenes are when Wilson is seen giving notes to his fellow musicians while recording the "Pet Sounds" album. Elizabeth Banks also turns in a fine performance as Wilson's second love, Melinda. Cusack, Dano, and Banks expertly provide much of the film's human touch. On the other hand there's Paul Giamatti as Wilson's ferocious therapist, who sounds like he may still be in the mindset of a disturbed antagonist from a different film set. Nonetheless, he gives another solid performance. Aside from stellar acting, the film itself is a revelation. The cinematography, editing, musical score, and sound mixing transcend the limits of traditional biopic filmmaking. There's even a sequence near the end of the film that will remind film buffs of the last ten minutes of '2001: A Space Odyssey'. It may baffle uninitiated viewers, but the sequence is truly no small feat for such an audacious picture. Only a few minor tweaks could be used its dialogue (which sounds ever-so-slightly clichï¿½d towards the end) and its pacing (some scenes carry on for a while), but 'Love & Mercy' is a near-perfect experience in terms of getting inside its subject's mind, heart and soul.

Great performances all around, especially from Dano and Cusack. The film dragged a bit in the middle, but it's still intriguing to soak in the life and artistry behind the talent through two different timelines. Also, Paul Giamatti is one scary dude.
Extremely weird, like Brian Wilson. Extremely unentertaining, unlike Brian Wilson.

An unorthodox biopic, but it works given Wilson's unusual and troubled life. While I was initially impatient during the quieter scenes featuring older Brian, the way that the two time periods come together is quite effective. Seeing the production and recording of several Beach Boys songs made me appreciate them and Wilson's musical genius so much more.

Paul Dano and John Cusack both provide believable performances, but the lack of any joy in Wilson's music makes for a deeply depressing experience. It may be factual but the movie leaves a bad taste in your mouth. Elizabeth Banks is spot on as usual and yes everyone will hate Paul Giamatti who brings evil to the screen as Eugene Landy. What a shame they completely missed what Wilson's music means to him and his fans.

Went to see this movie as we are Boomer's and love the music. I was very disappointed as they did little to show the talent and music that this group consistently produced. What the did was show how screwed up Brian Williams was, with less focus on his talent. We got up and left about 3/4 through the movie. We already saw a movie on Brian on TV, so we knew the story already! Don't waste your money...
Excellent. Pushes you to reflect on your own demons. Even sat through the closing credits.

An interesting, if not entirely accurate portrayal of the life of Brian Wilson. The film is free-wheeling and as out there in a way that fits Wilson's life well. By juxtaposing early and later life moments, it ties together an interesting tale that slowly peels back layers of Wilson's life like an onion, slowly. Both the script and direction are unique, while Dano and Cusak deliver Oscar-worthy performances.
Great performances all the way around. Good script. Innovative approaches take the audience inside the music and the man.

This is an auteur-like movie. By that I mean there is a lot of meandering mostly by Brian Wilson (played by Paul Dano & John Cusack). Although both Dano and Cusack are good, but it's really Elizabeth Banks who saves this movie.

This is certainly a film that Beach Boys fans will want to see. I'm a fan, so I may be biased... the roles are well played. The editing is quirky. Melinda, the woman who eventually marries Brian Wilson (after his divorce and following conservatorship by his therapist); is the hero of the movie; rescuing Wilson from his "evil captor", the therapist played by Paul Giamatti. Giamatti plays his role intensely, maybe too much so; but it allows the audience to identify him as the antagonist. Paul Dano does a fine job of playing the younger Brian Wilson in all of his moods and possessions, and John Cusack (haven't seen him in any films for awhile) performs convincingly as the emotionally tortured Brian Wilson in his later years.
Loved it- but Brian's music has always gone straight into me like no other.

Catnip to us Boomers who love the Beach Boys, of course, but it's SO much more than that. We rarely get to see "close ups" of a creative genius at work OR get to see the price paid for art. Paul Dano is a revelation. Elizabeth Banks gets to show off her "chops" beyond Effie (Hunger Games) and Gayle (Pitch Perfect). Paul Giamatti gets to go "full Giamatti" and that's always fun. If a new generation discovers "Pet Sounds," so much the better.

Love & Mercy is the best movie of the year so far. This film has a magnificent cast including Elizabeth Banks gives the performance of her career, Paul Giamatti giving a usual compelling performance. But John Cusack and Paul Dano give Academy Award worthy performances playing the current and past Brian Wilson. Love & Mercy is a smart, heartbreaking look at the genius that was and is, Brian Wilson. Do not miss out on this one!
Excellent acting! Sad story, I had no idea!

I am not an artistic genius. I am a relatively sensitive, creative guy. So... this movie kind of wrecked me. Of course, I went it believing 'Pet Sounds' to be a kind of musical scripture, so this was already right in the middle of my wheelhouse. Do NOT skip this because you think it will follow musical biopic tropes. It does not. Do NOT skip this movie because you don't care about Brian Wilson or the Beach Boys. That doesn't matter. Every actor deserves praise. I think this is Cusack's hour. I think Dano deserves an Oscar. I was holding back tears from the moment Brian brings up Dennis's death. I doubt I'll see a better film this year. (The Force Awakens comes out this year.)
Has anyone seen this film? it has great reviews.
A little long, and a little slow, but a very good movie, well worth seeing. Again, real life provides a lot more drama and emotional involvement than most script based stuff.

I do not go to very many movies in a theater but I could not wait to see Love & Mercy. I would have paid $20.00 if I needed to see this movie. The movie was brillient! I loved it. Throughout the entire movie, the audience was quiet and taking it all in and then laughing at times when something was funny. I love Brian Wilson and the Beach Boys. Thank you for sharing your painful and triumphant life story. I remember when everything was in the news. You are a true survivor and genius.
A truly wonderful film. I'm just so happy that Brian Wilson lived to sing on.

I've got mixed feelings about "Love & Mercy." Being a longtime Brian Wilson/Beach Boys fan, I find it entertaining, yet hard to watch. I enjoy the music and the inside look at Brian's life, but to see the turmoil, anguish and stress on his life was sad to watch. I'm not totally sold on the choice of Paul Dano and John Cusack playing the young/older Brian Wilson. For Beach Boy/Brian Wilson, "Love & Mercy" is a must see...once. Then go home and listen to their greatest hits, and feel your true appreciation for the genius that Brian Wilson was, and still is today. My favorite part of the movie the writing and production of the Beach Boy classic "Good Vibrations."

Quite honestly, I expected to enjoy this more than I actually did. The movie seemed too long and, having grown up during this time period, I didn't really learn anything I didn't know about the times or the Beach Boys. It was tedious to me.

Biopics are typically a boring "best-of" montage, episodic without any real arc. This one is completely different, a real breath of fresh air. Its parallel timelines are intriguing, and the creative process (as well as psychological strain) brought to vivid life. The fantastic ensemble cast turn in wonderfully passionate performances. And the sound design - oh, man, that sound design is just brilliant.
This was really good. Heartfelt and nuanced performances from Dano and Cusack made it worth the watch (plus the great music). Best movie of the year so far for me.

Love and Mercy was just enough off kilter to keep me interested and guessing what would happen next. Tremendous acting by the cast, especially Paul Dano & John Cusack. The story line was riveting & heartbreaking as the biopic follows Brian Wilson's struggle with the after-effects of abuse from his Father and the subsequent drug abuse and mental problems. Not necessarily a feel-good movie, but a story of survival by one of the great musicians of our time.

For music or culture fans this is a fascinating look into the troubled mind of musical genius Brian Wilson of the Beach Boys. I grew up in Southern California, and the band's hit 'I Get Around' was the first record I ever bought with my own money at 15. I thought I knew something about the band, but this movie was a real eye opener. We see great performances from everyone involved, especially Paul Dano and John Cusack as the young prodigy and the older Brian, fighting to break the figurative chains thrown on him by his Dr. and keeper, Eugene Landy, played to an almost over the top crescendo by Paul Giamatti. Elizabeth Banks is perfect as the woman who rescues him and literally saves his life. One of the best movies of the year.

This is a movie movie, which doesn't necessarily recommend it for a mainstream audience. It's for Beach Boys fan(atic)s, musicologists, and movie nerds who like unconventional efforts for the sake of unorthodoxy (which helps explain the cult adoration of Tarantino and Pulp Fiction). The parts (Dano, Cusack, Giamatti's scenery-chewing, clinical insights into Brian's muse and his music-making process) are greater than their sum. Having said that, it's one of the very few films of recent note I could stand to see again. Go figure.
Digs deep. Not just a basic biography.
@Brian Wilson The Mad genius

"Love & Mercy" is a biopic based on the life of Brian Wilson, the lead singer of The Beach Boys. The film lapses between Wilson's younger self (Paul Dano) and his older, more conflicted self (John Cusack). In the film, Wilson suffers from paranoid schizophrenia, and Paul Giamatti, his legal guardian, controls him incessantly and wants to impede him from having a relationship with his love interest (Elizabeth Banks) for his supposed "own good." Though I thought the film was an interesting biopic with some good studio scenes, I thought the narrative was uneven in parts and that some of the plot was lagging. If I was producing a movie on the life of the Beach Boys, I would focus more on the music and the legacy than painting Wilson as an impotent drool monkey, which I feel the film does. His character is entirely under the whim of Giamatti, which I feel detracts from Wilson's legacy. The film also does not feature "Kokomo," which was the band's biggest hit, an exclusion that is unforgivable in my book. I'm not also sure that Paul Dano really captured the essence of Wilson and instead made him look like a self-righteous bigot who only wanted to write his own songs and go against the grain of his fellow group members. The film was a nice character study, but it lacked the narrative holism I was looking for ---------------------------------------------------------------------------------- B-
Is it true that the Beach Boys could not swim ?

Went in to this trusting that Paul Dano would do well, but tentative that John Cusack could hold his own. Turns out I actually may have liked Cusack's performance even better. The best he's been in years. And yes, Dano was incredible, too.
Some outstanding performances by Cusack, Banks and Giamatti. Dano IS Wilson, looking like him, sounding like him and, in essence, being him. Oscar worthy performance by Dano.

This movie felt like a mental illness. There was so little story that I felt like I was the one on LSD. Great acting and imagery, just very little plot. Paul Giamatti and John Cusack once again show just how great they are at acting but their talents are almost wasted. I don't know how many times I asked myself, "Is this trip ever going to end?" And that's not a compliment.

a very interesting portrait of Brian Wilson that examines his mental health issues and his musical genius. It would have been a better movie if Jon Cusack gained 50 pounds :D Once you get by his looking nothing like Brian, or the other actors portraying the young Brian, he really gives a great performance. Paul Dano is wonderful, and really helps capture the spirit of Brian Wilson and the Beach Boys. The music is great, and not enough for me, but I guess it was enough. They really show the brilliant producing and writing of Brian back in the 1960's.
Great bio-pic. Fascinating story with beautiful music.

Love and Mercy is the latest in a series of biopics that have been coming out lately. I wouldn't normally consider this to be my genre, but I give them credit for making a convincing trailer. I went in hoping for a movie about the creative process and a thoughtful look into the mind that creates great music. I was not disappointed...sort of. In a way, it did it all too well. Sometimes the overly romanticized creative process is actually an unpleasant hellscape, full of delusions, hearing voices, self doubt - in other words, sometimes creating something means you must experience the opposite of that thing. Instead of feeling invigorated as I hoped, I was given a sharp dose of reality. One other thing to go along with that, apparently Brian Williams was into drugs for a period of his life and suffered from some schizophrenia. In some parts, I found myself having a hard time figuring out what they're going for, but so did Brian Wilson as he lived through it. So I can't fault them completely for being occasionally incoherent. All that being said, the movie is very well made with a lot of very touching scenes. The actors are well placed, especially the two leads. (though I must admit that I was more intrigued when the Paul Dano side of the story came up on the screen.) The story is good, and I love movies like this that dig deep into how the human mind works. There's a large portion of movie goers that would find the movie too slow and many scenes unnecessary and nonsensical. Fortunately for this movie, I doubt many of those people would ever find themselves watching it anyway. My Grade: B-

Imagine a '2001: A Space Odyssey' style movie patchwork building to an overall storyline arc applied to Brian Wilson's life. This is the story of Brian Wilson's life and it is also an intimate journey through mental illness, the 60's music scene, the Wrecking Crew, music recording and more. Cheers to John Cusack, Elizabeth Banks and Paul Dano!Shame on Hollywood for the poor and limited distribution.

Paul Dano and John Cusack create an amazing duet as Brian Wilson in the bloom of youth careening toward an emotional break and Brian WIlson a broken soul who is lost and trying to find his way back. Elizabeth Banks understated performace never hits a false note as a woman who is an emotional life line to Wilson. The soundtrack is amazing and that from someone who has really never been a Beach Boys fan. The direction is smart and tight and the script avoids most of the cliches that burden biographical material. It is too bad that this beautifully realized film is out so early in the year because Paul Dano deserves some awards season love for his portrait of Wilson as a tortured young genius
An Excellent boi-pic weaving the past and present into superb entertainment.Fantastic performances all around

The one problem for me was...... it felt like they spliced two different movies. At no point did I believe that Paul Dano and John Cusack were the same person. Given the time span of the movie, there is no reason Dano with the help of makeup shouldn't done the whole movie.

All performances are great- Cusck was fourth best, and HE was amazing. Giammatti was terrifying as Eugene Landy; really menacing. Paul Dano is extraordinary as young Brian Wilson. If you like the Beach Boys, even a little, this is a must see.
The Pauls -- Dano and Giamatti -- carry this movie, which is arguably a bit one-sided but contains music that is unarguably great.
So glad I saw this flick!

Easily one of the best rock biopics ever, at least, if not the best. LeeAnne and I saw Landy and Wilson at a movie theater in W. Hollywood when we were dating. Something looked off, just watching them together. Even if you don't care about the music or people, it's a fascinating film. Go see it!
Got to see this tonight. Great movie. Biographies can be tough t watch sometimes because they try to include to much. This film finds the right balance wanting you to draw conclusions. Loved it.

Fantastic movie seamlessly mixing the Brian-Past's Pet Sounds and Smile recording era and Brian-Future's struggles with Dr. Landy's demonic grasp on Brian, Love & Mercy is a fantastic biopic and engaging movie.
How do you not love the Beach Boys? Music, lyrics exudes good vibration. I did not know Brian Wilson story. Tragic but he was saved by love. Inspiring. See it.

This movie sucks. If you are unable to sleep, I highly recommend this snoozer. I love BB music, at least up to and including Good Vibrations, a fav. Forget Smile. Only see this movie if you want a glimmer of all of Brian's problems and/or how his "therapist" thoroughly controlled him and ripped him off financially (and know that it was even worse in real life). The 2 best parts of this film were (1) the opening segments giving a flavor of them performing in the early 60s, and (2) The beauty of Elizabeth Banks (I could watch her all day and not get bored). Not that the acting wasn't good. Just that the movie was slow, not enough of their music and too much of the tragedy that was an integral part of Brian's life. My life is a lot poorer and my dad was abusive but he didn't hit me evey day and kill my right ear and sell all my music rights for $750K. How this movie was rated so high is beyond me -- and nowhere near as entertaining as Entourage (which got nowhere near as high a rating). I only wish I could have gone to see another movie right after this one -- to get the sour taste out of my mouth.
So many movies are forgettable but this one has stayed with me for two weeks. I loved it.

This movie perfectly illustrates the struggle and madness of being an artist perfectly. It also interestingly sheds light on the life of Brian Wilson in a way some people, including myself, may not have realized. John Cusack is wonderful as always. Elizabeth Banks surprisingly wields the helm of her role excellently. Paul Dano's career has been set on the map after this role, coming a long way from his early days in "Little Miss Sunshine". The flow of this script and the presentation of the material is perfect, possibly making it a future oscar nominee.

Paul Dano and John Cusack offer two exceptional performances as Wilson in two distinct (and at times even contrasting) stages of his life, and this insightful biopic is very well directed, beautifully photographed and filled with the wonderful music of The Beach Boys.

It's an amazing film that was intriguing at every moment, and sucked me in with every twist and turn. This film redefines the Musician Biopic genre and gives it a fresh, palatable sweet and bold flavor that will leave you feeling love. Fantastic!

Disappointing. A lot of Brian Wilson's odd behavior and not enough Beach Boys music. They only played very brief moments of their hit songs, if at all. Not one word or note from some of the groups biggest songs such as 'California Girls' , ' Sail on Sailor' or 'Kokomo'.
Fantastic movie and very well acted

"Love & Mercy" is less a bionic than it is a true examination of a life time of mental illness. In this film, we are introduced to an already flourishing Beach Boys with their fandom at an all time high, leaving the band at this point to hit the daunting task of staying on par in order to keep relevant. We're shown through an opening mini montage that the band is already famous, so from there its off and running. I appreciated that about this film. Its not intended to be a biopic about how the Beach Boys came to be. Its center is more thoughtful and interesting than that.I think these days its important to mix things up if you're planning on making a true and honest character piece about a famous person's life. "Love& Mercy" is that film. Its spends its full running time explaining to us, the audience who Brian Wilson is, why we should care, and what makes him not only interesting, but so important to music history. This film does what I to this day believe that "Walk the line" should have with telling the Johnny Cash story. It uses non-linear story telling to get the audience more invested in the presentation of the film, instead of simply hitting the bullet points of Brian Wilson's life. There are many open holes and unanswered questions come the end of the film. That's the beauty of it. Life doesn't work the way a movie usually displays it."Walk the line" faltered simply because it didn't want to confuse its audience or disrespect the subject matter, but what if that's what Cash would have wanted? He too was an open book and one large unanswered question. "Walk the line" was a watered down version of the actual events that he himself describes in his very own autobiography "Cash". So perhaps he would have wanted a more honest and brash depiction instead of the stiflingly boring "Walk the line". The reason I bring this up is to prove a point. Biopics are tricky. They can easily fall into fluff pieces with too much of the artists music in the background and not enough exposition of the reality of things in which case they can become self parodies."Love & Mercy" takes all the conventions of the usual biopic and flips it on its head. It tells two completely different stories in two completely different times in Brian Wilson's life. Its the juxtaposed story telling here that sets "Love & Mercy" apart from all the rest. One story being told in the mid 60s and the other in the late 80s. Two completely different narratives with completely different styles of film making. Paul Dano plays the young Wilson in the 60s as he struggles to exist with the other members of the band and battles the early stages of his illness. John Cusack plays the older Wilson having been babysat literally for most of his adult years by his shady therapist played by a very creepy Paul Giamatti.The 60s scenes play out more of the traditional biopic style with us witnessing Wilson's genius as he writes and creates "Pet Sounds" which is believed by many to be one of the best albums of all time. Paul Dano is magnificent as a young Wilson obsessed with his music to the point where we wonder if he ever needed the Beach Boys. His mannerisms are amazing and his look really makes you feel the performance. The supporting cast of the other members are all really good as well and it was good to see that they were not shut out of the film and reduced to extras like all the members of The Doors in Oliver Stone's "The Doors".The scenes in the 80s are more the after math of what we see from the 60s, plus a lot more that we apparently don't see. John Cusack, in his best performance in probably 20 years nails it as the already broken Wilson. Here he meets Melinda, played with poise and grace by Elizabeth Banks and we witness a real friendship start and blossom into an amazingly sweet and intense romance. Cusack really becomes the Wilson that we've seen in the more recent interviews with his high dose of meds making him dry mouthed and constantly licking his lips. Everything from the way he stands, walks, and flicks his finger tips, we really feel as we are watching Wilson and not Cusack, which I guess is the point. Elizabeth Banks surprises as many of the heavy scenes are carried by her as she watches Wilson unravel all over again. Its heartbreaking watching what Wilson went through at the same time infuriating watching how his therapist manipulated him for so many years. Giamatti was really fantastic. Its not easy to hate Giamatti, but here, you really really do.I applaud this film for making something different. It has the courage to try and make us think of what happened between these two timelines. They never meet right in the middle, only mere suggestion of whats to come. The story telling is what really sells this picture. The acting is first rate and the writing is perfect. I'm not entirely sure if this type of film hits what the academy looks for when it comes to best picture, however, I'd like to think some consideration will be in order when it comes to the acting and perhaps the writing. Time will tell. Either way, this is a pretty great film. In addition, we are treated with the experience of watching how the album "Pet Sounds" was created and it is truly a joy to see how that happened.

Successful producer Bill Pohlad (Brokeback Mountain; Into the Wild; 12 Years a Slave; The Tree of Life) has made the move into the director's seat with some astonishing results. Love & Mercy is an amazing biopic, and Beach Boys genius Brian Wilson - simultaneously played in the past and present respectively by Paul Dano and John Cusack - is a fascinating enigma to behold. The Screenplay by Oren Moverman (The Messenger; I'm Not There) and Michael Lerner deftly bounces back and forth between the 1960's when Brian Wilson was succumbing to paranoia and delusions while crafting musical masterpieces and the 1980's where he lives as a prisoner under the care of a ruthless therapist. In the 1960's, Wilson is portrayed by Paul Dano (There Will Be Blood; Little Miss Sunshine) was gives the best performance of his young career. Dano captures all the tender genius in Wilson's heart. And if Dano is the heart of the movie, Cusack is the soul. The veteran actor plays Wilson in the 1980's where he meets the lovely Cadillac saleswoman Melinda - played by a red-hot Elizabeth Banks - and struggles to make human contact while drugged-up by his surreptitious benefactors. Cusack and Banks create quite a unique love story as she deals with Cusack's fragile emotional state and the ego-maniacal terror embodied by Paul Giamatti's Dr. Landy. Cusack and Dano could perform the unheard of feat of both earning Oscar nominations for playing the same character in the same film. Banks and Giamatti are equally worthy. And props to the technicians! Along with the perfect soundscape, The Grand Budapest Hotel's cinematographer Robert D. Yeoman beautifully renders the 1960's with grainy period lighting and film stock. The production team expertly captures time and place with art direction and costuming. Who wouldn't know it was 1985 when Elizabeth Banks slinks in with her electronic blue dress straight out of Cybil Shepherd's Moonlighting wardrobe?Love & Mercy should be discovered by all adult audiences.
Loved it. Stay for the credits.
Awesome biopic on Brian Wilson. The music is great. The acting is great. One thing I did find a little distracting was some shaky camera work but other than that great film.
Moving. Fame and wealth can't insulate you from mental illness and exploitation. Brilliantly acted. As good as it gets.
Absolutely loved it - great performances by both actors playing the part of Brian Wilson (Paul Dano and John Cusack)
WOW, insightful and heart touching.
A fairly unconventional biopic that uses a non-linear storyline and arthouse-esque cinematography...and still feels a trite bit cliched.

Had a chance to obtain an early viewing of the film and I approached it with a positive bias since I've been a big fan of the Beach Boys during their prime (1960-1970) given that Brian Wilson was one of the most talented songwriters of his day, even if he lost his magic touch some time ago. Unfortunately, the film happens to be a tremendous disappointment on several levels. First, when casting a living celebrity who is recognizable to millions, it is imperative to find an actor(s) that bears some physical resemblance to the icon...or, at the least, convert the actor via makeup, hair dye, prosthetics, etc., into an acceptable simulacrum. As much as I like Cusack, at no time could I suspend disbelief and think of him as "Brian Wilson," not for a moment. Second, the film had the feeling of a TV Movie of the Week, thanks primarily to the wooden dialogue and the mundane, conventional, directorial interpretation. This biopic, in the hands of a far more talented writer such as Aaron Sorkin and a more imaginative director such as Milos Forman, likely would have been an extraordinary creation, since the life of Brian Wilson is genuinely a fascinating rise-fall-resurrection tale. Essentially, what the film really needed were powerful visual biographers who could awe the audience in the same manner that Brian Wilson could blow away his fans, thanks to his oft, out-of-the-box songs, such as, "Good Vibrations." Unfortunately, where Brian Wilson's songs could be astounding works of art, this biopic only will appeal to those hard core oldster fans (the majority now firmly ensconced within their senile years) who worship the man as a veritable god, ready to fall in love with any mediocre mention or trite paean to his life. Yes, it was very nice to hear all those Beach Boys songs again...but, hell, today, I can steal all of the music for free from the internet, so why would I pay a single penny for the experience? Sorry to report that Love & Mercy is more in the vein of "Banal Vibrations," and can only recommend this for a free TV viewing, and merely for those who might find it of academic interest.

This is a very interesting movie. It's not about the Beach Boys music but primarily focus' on Brian Wilson's demons. If you don't know which of the Beach Boys is Brian and can't name two other members of the group, I don't think you will enjoy this very much.

A mediocre movie made better by the lead actors and their performances. The chemistry between Elizabeth Banks and John Cusack is amazing, and makes their portions of the film captivating, but Paul Dano - while giving a great performance - isn't given enough material to really look forward to or enjoy his parts. Banks deserves an Oscar nomination, the best performance of her career.

Thoroughly absorbing and brilliantly executed, the bio-pic of American's boy genius of 60's sun, surf, sand, parties, cars and cruising for girls, follwed by his later pop music #1 mega hit Good Vibrations, is a unique exploration of the haunting combination of musical genius almost blocked out due to emotional and mental delusions making every day life painful, first at the hands of his violent, abusive and dismissive father followed by total emotional domination and exploittation by his full time therapist Eugene Landy (well played by Paul Giamatti with a bad toupee [is there any other kind?]}. As played by Giamatti, "therapist" Landy was the portriat of wickedness masquerading as full time TLC. The idea of two physically different, facially different actors, both well known for other work (especially the always watchable John Cusack) along with the less known but possessing first rate acting chops by Paul Dano as the young Beach Boy founder, a better character study is not know by this reviewer. Paul Dano plays the younger Brian tormented by his constantly critical father as well as lead singer cousin Mike Love who doesn't understand Brian's constant search for new sounds, instruments, counterpoint harmonies and musical exploration. The film opens with Cusack as the elder Brian shoeless "test sitting" a Cadillac Fleetwood in a showroom when his future wife Melinda (empathically played with just right touch of strength, curiosity and vulnerability by Elizabeth Banks (recently director of Pitch Perfect 2 as well as Efie Trinket of the Hunger Games series) makes a deal to sell him a car. Adding to the realism is the director's choice to not just play original Beach Boys finished songs as the film moves from one hit phase to another, interrupted by Brian's mental problems. Rather the skeletal song parts are there supplemented by the actors' singing whle making records in the studio. As is always the case, there is no substitute for a good story. Briam Wilson's long anguished journey from tormented, shy, introverted emerging songwriter barely 20 years old, dreaming of his Surfer Girl In My Room who later emerges as a bloated, sleep addicted psyedelic LSD tripster who falls under the spell of Landy. Cerebral and engaging, Love and Mercy has both.

One of the top films of 2015. Love & Mercy is a tour-de-force of acting and visual craft. As erratic, unexpected and joyous as the noisy mind of Brian Wilson. Rarely, has a biopic been made that accurately depicts the wresting demons of an artist quite like this one. Many try, and fail. This one has a bevy of material to work with, and doesn't waste a drop. Paul Dano, once again, gives a performance that will leave you speechless. It astounds me how vastly overlooked he is an an actor. His work in Little Miss Sunshine and There Will Be Blood should've garnered him two Oscar nominations by now. John Cusack gives another Oscar worthy performance as the older Brian Wilson. This is essential two stories in one. The rocky rise of Brian Wilson, and the love story of his later years. Each connect due to the two people in his life that keep him from living; his abusive father and his abusive, leaching, Hollywood psychotherapist, played incredibly by Paul Giamatti. Elizabeth Banks also gives a pretty impressive turn as Melinda. After leaving the theater, I've fallen in love with The Beach Boys all over again. This is the movie fans have been waiting for. You don't want to miss this one, folks.

it's nice when a movie surprises you these days with how good it is. The Paul Dano sequences are fantastic. Very compassionate and absorbing. Extra points for employing the wonderful composer Atticus Ross
Great film, music and concept. See it

Brilliant performances from actors/singers who recreate the unique sounds of the Beach Boys and tormented genius of Brian Wilson. Uplifting and disturbingfor one of the greatest muscial talents and his journey towards ultimate inner peace.
Incredible performances and deeply moving film.

As Pet Sounds is the perfect album so is Love and Mercy the perfectly created biopic of Brian Wilson's whacked-out genius . Dano and Cusack are terrific as young and older Brian. The re-creation of the studio sessions of PS and SMILE are pure magic. Elizabeth Banks (very stunning in an 80's way) plays his second wife Melinda who is Brian's loving antidote to an overbearing father Murry Wilson (Bill Camp is great) bloodsucking shrink Eugene Landy (bad wig Paul Giamatti) and irritatingly short-sighted cousin Mike Love. This one made me SMILE big time! Best movie of 2015 by a wide margin. (6-13-15)

Cusack has his moments but it's Dano's movie, and he's pretty convincing as the budding genius about to crack up. The scenes in the studio - creating and obsessing - are the best of this uneven biopic.

I gave the movie 3 stars for Paul Dano's brilliant performance, the music and insight into mental illness. John Cusack was all wrong for the part and awful to watch. I would like to have given it 4 stars, but Cusack was just too awful to watch.

This was an amazing movie - the best movie I've seen all year. While I would have loved more music, the inside look at recording of their most famous songs, and the remarkable portrayals by Paul Dano and John Cusack of Brian Wilson's genius and sadness, was mesmerizing. This is a must-see for everyone who loved the Beach Boys, or simply appreciates a great, true story.

I didn't know that much going in....AND I WAS BLOWN AWAY. This movie has stayed with me for weeks and weeks. And has led to a Paul Dano other movie hunt by the way. This real story of Brian Wilson is at times hard to watch but ultimately most awesome.

This movie was a jumbled, confusing mess. The use of two different actors for the main character was confusing and a foolish casting decision. It just didn't jell or compute. I also think the blonde actress always looked more like a model then a real person. Another bad casting decision. The movie was so poorly directly Hollywood should be ashamed. Other movies about famous people were a lot more interesting and satisfying...Coal Miners Daughter and Walk the line.Save your money.

Unfortunately, genius and mental illness sometimes go hand-in-hand. Too often, the kind of genius that represents truly original thought is so unusual that it's perceived as "crazy", but sometimes when a term like that is used for someone who thinks and acts very differently than others, it refers to a literal, clinically-defined mental or emotional impairment. In those cases, the issue becomes whether the mental illness is the cause or the result of the sick person's genius. It's a kind of chicken-egg question, but no matter which came first, mental illness hurts. It hurts the person suffering from it and those who care about him or her and, left untreated (or poorly treated), it can destroy those interpersonal relationships and, of course, the person who is ill - genius and all. This was the problem, and nearly the fate, of Brian Wilson, founder of The Beach Boys. Wilson's struggle is the focus of the innovative and insightful biopic "Love & Mercy" (PG-13, 2:01).Part of the problem in describing this movie is that the term "biopic" applies only in the loosest sense. This film is not a valentine to the Beach Boys, or even a chronicle of all the important events in the life of Wilson himself. The story's unusual structure is meant to convey a single major issue in his life - an ongoing struggle with mental illness. The plot revolves around two pivotal periods in Wilson's personal history - the late 1960s and the late 1980s - when his illness began to have a significant effect on his life, and, later, when the treatment he received was exposed as more harmful than helpful and Wilson was able to start receiving proper care. Constructed as it is, the film's creative team decided to have two actors play Wilson - Paul Dano for the earlier portion of the story and John Cusack for the later part. Those separate periods in Wilson's life unfold throughout the movie, which skillfully alternates between scenes from each, similar to the way "The Godfather, Part II" tells its tale, but without the sense that the earlier scenes are flashbacks. Both stories are told chronologically and as if they are happening simultaneously, both bringing Wilson's life to points of crisis and ultimately, to redemption.The late 1960s' Brian Wilson was a young genius, at the height of his powers. A few well-chosen scenes (displayed as if they're bits of genuine archival footage) show The Beach Boys at their most popular - clean-cut California kids cranking out hit after feel-good hit. By the late 60s, most of their biggest hits are behind them and Wilson is trying to move the band in new directions, gaining inspiration from his natural musical talent, innate creativity, some illicit drugs, and the voices and music that he hears in his head. The main focus in the late 60s scenes is the production of the classic album "Pet Sounds", which was critically acclaimed (and is now considered one of the greatest albums of all time), but was dispassionately received by many Beach Boys fans due to its radical departure from the band's signature upbeat songs. Except for a few scenes in which we see the band create "Good Vibrations", the focus is not so much on the music as on the man. It's a very human story which is both more personal and more relatable than a traditional biopic.The late 1980s' Brian Wilson is a broken man being rebuilt by the radical 24-hour therapy of his psychiatrist and legal guardian, Dr. Eugene Landy (Paul Giamatti). There are bits of dialog to let us know how Wilson got to this point and how much Landy did to bring him back from the brink, but most of what we see in these portions of the story is the complete control that Landy exercises over his patient's daily life and personal affairs. Landy, or those on his staff, follow Wilson everywhere he goes. We can tell by the way Wilson talks and acts that he needs some level of supervision. What isn't as clear is whether his need for Landy's care has more to do with Wilson's actual mental state, the huge amount of medication Landy has Wilson taking or the near complete physical, mental and emotional dependence that Landy has caused Wilson to have on him. This is the situation that Melinda Ledbetter (Elizabeth Banks) walks into. She's a former model who is now selling cars. She and Brian meet when he comes to buy a Cadillac from the dealership where she works. In spite of Wilson's off-beat way of talking, Melinda is drawn to his sweet and fragile disposition and it's obvious that Wilson is immediately attracted to her too. As the two grow closer and Landy allows her, as he says "unprecedented access" to Wilson's life, she sees Landy's manipulations for what they are and feels compelled to help, regardless of the cost. Those who can watch "Love & Mercy" without being distracted by the unconventional story-telling style are likely to find it both enlightening and enjoyable. The film provides rare insights into mental illness and shines a light on the need for the families and friends of such patients to remain active and attentive regarding their loved one's care. Beach Boys fans, and really, all music fans, will enjoy seeing the creative process behind one of the most important influences in the history of American popular music. And those who like a good romance or human drama will get that too. Last but not least, movie fans will appreciate the outstanding performances and will likely hope, as I do, that they are remembered come the next awards season. However, the film has a few too many slow moments, it could have done a better job of filling in some of the obvious gaps in the story, and the prevailing tone of the film is a little depressing, but its compelling story told in such an original way with such great actors outweighs its few imperfections. "B+"
Paul Dano was amazing as Brian Wilson. John Cusak was a major miscast.

Depressingly honest portrayal of The Beach Boys' Brian Wilson's path through the darkness of psycopathology. I will never listen to a Beach BOys song again without feeling the blistering pain and torment of their gifted leader. This is truly a story of man's inhumanity to man. granted he eventually finds peace but the vast majority of the movie lives in his torment. There should be an Academy Award nomination here for John Cusack and perhaps Paul DAno and Paul Giamatti. Serious movie with serious themes and serious energy. The sound track is both fun and grating depending whether it's the song as it was recorded or the song amidst the voices in his head.
Good story, good performances. Could have used more of the music. Sad tale, but nice to know he came out the other side. Giamatti is effective in his creepiness.

+I had a hard time getting into, letting alone understanding, "Love and Mercy" and more than once during the first hour I wanted to bolt the theatre but I stayed and finally figured it all out!While the bulk of the film is carried by John Cusack and Paul Dano, both as Brian Wilson, it is the performance by Elizabeth Banks that holds it all together. Dano is Brian during the late 60s and we see how he wrote the music that would become a thread in so many lives while Cusack plays Brian in the 1980s who came under the control of a manipulative shyster, Dr. Eugene Landy, played by Paul Giamatti, who just oozes evil, who was given all legal control of the musician's life, though how is not really explained. Banks is Melinda Ledbetter who meets the latter Brian and sees the man he really is, who helps him get away from Landy and would eventually marry him.This is not a play by the numbers Hollywood biography though there are many elements from the abused children angle to the real possibility of a man being easily dominated by another father figure. Yes there are the drugs, the high living, the 'mad' genius aspect but this is more of getting into the head of a songwriter and how and where the music comes from and into his descent into an unexplainable diagnosis as a paranoid schizophrenia with hearing voices and LSD which doesn't help him.There is no resemblance between Dano and Cusack nor do they ever move or talk the same but both are believable as being the same man. Many of Wilson's hit songs are heard but not as in a concert but how they sprang from the man's mind. One example is how much the difference of the sound between a father slapping his son so hard that the latter loses most of his hearing in that ear and a spanking can bring different tones to a song. Another prime example of what made Wilson such a perfect musician was his search for the exact sound of the cellists in "Good Vibrations".There is not a false movement by any of the cast and the direction by Bill Pohlad, with the screenplay by Oren Moverman and Michael Alan Lerner, take this far away from 'just another musical Hollywood biography'. The sound editing by Atticus Ross and the sound mixing by Edward Tise are works of perfection.This is not an easy film to watch, get into and/or understand but it is worth the 2 hours of your life to watch it--and how many movies can you say that about?
Well acted movie. I had no idea about this story before seeing it. I thought John Cusack was excellent in the role. It was just a little bit too long.
Great show. Perhaps a little hard on Eugene Landy, but not by much.

I just saw the movie today. It was good, but not great. If you are already a Brian Wilson fan, there is nothing new here--you know the story. If you are a casual fan of the Beach Boys or don't know much about Brian Wilson, you will really like the film. Giamatti's(Landy character) wig is awful, but he plays the role well.

Pohlad makes a film with the total lack of constraints that made Pet Sounds one of the greatest albums of the 1960s. But Pohlad's no Brian Wilson, whatever his similar feelings and family life may be like. The film relies on the virtuosity of its cast and cinematographer which are the best money can buy, watching Steve McQueen direct does not make a director.

This movie is about Bryan Wilson, lead singer/songwriter of the Beach Boys so there was a good showing of Old Geezers Who Go To The Matinee alone; this was 'our' era after all. I mostly went because it started at the right time but boy o boy was I surprised. This is a very serious and completely effective movie. The music, of course, is central but it is about Bryan Wilson's mental issues and the people who surrounded him. Pal Dano plays a young Bryan and John Cusack plays him as an adult. Both deserve awards for these nearly faultless performances. Elizabeth Banks, an actor who has had her ups and downs, is terrific as the person who ultimately saves Bryan from the clutches of the psychologist played by Paul Giamatti. I didn't see a single bad note in this movie although it is not all that easy to watch. If you were into the Beach Boys and music of that time you'll enjoy it. A very real movie so don't go expecting to rock and roll.

When you think of the iconic band "The Beach Boys" you invariablythink of sunshine, beach, surfacing, good times..... "Good Vibrations" Wellthe new movie "Love and Mercy" staring John Cusack, Paul Giamatti, ElizabethBanks and Paul Dano (as the young Brian Wilson) is quick the opposite. While showing the utter musical genius of Brian Wilson, the film focuses onhis mental illness issues that start early on and journey right thru middleage. Besides an abusive Father, sort of non supportive brothers and cousins,Wilson ends up being heavily medicated, monitored and controlled by a whack jobtherapist/legal guardian (never really explained) played really well by PaulGiamatti. The latters role is very reminiscent of the "controlling" role playedby Steve Carell (Academy Award Nominee) in Foxcatcher/2014...a sick, scary, weird,faux father figure with ulterior motives.Elizabeth Banks plays Cusack's love interest who is a very strong, independentand successful woman who clearly sees the real Brian Wilson (and inner horror he's going thru). I must admit I was moreso distracted by howimpeccably dressed she was in many different scenes. Not something I normallynotice but boy did she visually steal every scene.This movie is very well done just not fun, summery, upbeat. Will not do wellin the box office as it plays to themes that are antithetical to themes onethinks of the Beach Boys. Would be a hard film to recommend to friends.

'Love & Mercy' is one of the best musical biopics of the last decade! Paul Dano and John Cusack are equally great in their own way. Dano is magnetic and Cusack is heartbreaking, his best performance in years! This is uniquely visual and it's use of sound is genius, especially it's different take visually on mental illness. Director Bill Pohlad comes out of nowhere with a spellbinding directing of tough subject matter. Elizabeth Banks is amazing in a performance that could get criminally under rated around awards season. This is a powerful and moving drama and you don't even have to like The Beach Boys either.

I really liked the film. My only issue was John Cusack. When Paul Dano was on the screen I believed I was watching Brian Wilson. Every time Cusack was on the screen I saw John Cussack. I wish that Dano would have played Wilson the entire film and they aged him.

Nothing like a biopic that shakes things up. Fittingly, the subject is Beach Boys maestro Brian Wilson, the innovative songwriter and composer whose musical experiments generated some of the most beautiful and iconic music of the 1960's. Instead of having one actor portray Wilson, who fought a long battle with drug addiction and mental illness, director Bill Pohlad gives us two terrific performances. First there's Paul Dano, who packed on some pounds to get Wilson's likeness just right for the 1960's version, when he was at the height of his artistic powers. Then there's John Cusack, looking very much unlike Wilson circa the 1980's, fighting against the pill-induced haze created by his therapist Eugene Landy (Paul Giamatti, totally nutty). He's rescued from oblivion by Cadillac saleswoman Melinda Ledbetter (Elizabeth Banks), who became his second wife.Ledbetter herself was a consultant on the script. Does her input stifle the film dramatically? Possible, probably. But the taught script from Oren Moverman and Michael Alan Lerner fights against lame cliches, as does Dino Jonsater's editing, which jumps between time periods until sharp juxtaposition generates true clarity. Musically, the film is outstanding. Just watch Wilson in the studio, wrangling musicians around while recording 'Good Vibrations' and his opus Pet Sounds, utilizing literal bells and whistles, along with bicycle bells and even barking dogs to get close to the music Wilson is hearing in his head. It's a sharp contrast from Cusack's performance, focusing on introspection. But it's Dano who is truly electrifying, award-caliber. Just try taking your eyes off him.

God only knows what would be of this year without this movie! Esta pelï¿½cula te hace feliz, te (re) enamora del cine, termina y quieres ver otra, deseas pasar la vida viendo solo pelï¿½culas... La pelï¿½cula examina la vida de Brian Wilson, compositor y cantante de los Beach Boys, pero va mï¿½s allï¿½, nos muestra cï¿½mo nace el arte y cï¿½mo surge el amor. Cada escena es emocionante (no hay una que no lo sea). El audio es un milagro. Los actores son maravillosos (a excepciï¿½n del rol exagerado de Giamatti). La mejor pelï¿½cula de este aï¿½o (hasta ahora).

Almost unbearable. Sometimes painfully dull and sometimes painfully painful. As a huge fan of the Beach Boys, Beatles and Doors I left feeling much the same after all three bio pics about the front men. Drug addled, self-indulgent and brilliant at times, they all dissolve rapidly before our eyes wasting their time and talent on chemical recreation with no concern or awareness of the toll it takes.
The best music bio ever made. This film is a high wire act...the jump cutting between decades using two different actors might have failed but instead it works to perfection.
I never realized that Brian Wilson was so talented and innovative.
John Cusack and Paul Dano are amazing. Love, love loved it!

I love Brian Wilson. I love Pet Sounds To hear about a biographical film of him and the time where he and The Beach Boys were working on the album, I know I had to go see this film. Also, to have Paul Dano casted as Wilson himself, I knew this was gonna be an emotional ride and indeed it was. I wasn't sure about John Cusak playing older Brian but seeing him as Brian, I was dead wrong.Me and eggsslut? saw Love and Mercy last night at the Arclight. It's such a great film that draws you into the world of a genius and his harsh struggles, also giving you insight of history being re-created right in front of your eyes. This film paid so much attention to detail as far as casting and the shit that was going down. I was obsessed with Pet Sounds when I first heard it (still am in a way). It's such a great album. There's so much in there and you only think that it was something being made but it's quite the opposite. A lot of creativity was put in there. A emotions were mixed in there fueled by the people very close to Brian. The stuff he did in there, people didn't think it would work or amount to anything for half of the part. It was way ahead of its time. Dano as well as Cusack played Brian so freakin' good. Dano has a good voice. I felt Cusack did a better job. I mean the state that Brian was in during that time, it takes somebody with that range and he pulled it of. I focused a lot on Cusack's hands, his eye and even his mouth. There's so much that he does with each of those things I mentioned. He played somebody who has problems and still be able to communicate with people well. Dano knows how to keep it together in his scenes. Brian was like that during his creative time in the Pet Sounds sessions. He was a very emotional guy and Dano brought out the need Brian wants from people. He was determined to make something beautiful. I love how the director casted the rest of the band and them involved during that process. I never thought Mike Love was that much of a dick during that time. I did know that their father was manager and that Brian was tired of making the same 'ol surf music. Older Brian's scenes were a bit more intense. Elizabeth Banks really impressed me with her acting. It's crazy how somebody can hold in through a lot for somebody who was just a customer for cars. Paul Giamatti scared the hell out of me. He always knew how to play wired up characters in any kind of genre. I never thought he can take it up a notch. The casting is great. They bring out the people very well, even for the session musicians. I recognize some of the musicians from archives photos. I just wished they focused bit more on the things Brian was doing when he was older or the things after Good Vibrations. I remember the scene where he was trying to pick out the vibes at a space but wasn't able to. I wish there was more to that. We see the things but we want to go deeper because we're used to see a lot already from this film, it's like can you go more? The sound editing is beautiful. That's where the heart is in the technical blueprints in this film. Hearing the voices Brian is listening, us eavesdropping on the things he would say to the musicians, him freaking out to the utensils in the dinner. As far as sound, that's one of my favorite 'cause they even managed to make a beat to it as it was going on. My favorite scene is probably the scene where Brian and Melinda sit in the car together. It was played out so well. I loved the dialogue and camera work in that scene. There's a cut where it lingered on Banks for quite a moment. The special car. Did he ever get that car? Wouldn't it be nice if he did?
This movie hit very close to home.

Great acting, great direction, great cinematography, great writing. A must see for anyone who likes music and especially the Beach Boys. Amazing attention to detail -- this is an extremely accurate bio-pic.

Love & Mercy is a film about Brian Wilson and his time as the lead singer of the legendary band The Beach Boys and after. The Young Brian Wilson is portrayed by Paul Dano and the older Brian Wilson is portrayed by John Cusack. Young Wilson is at the peak of his creativity while making the famous Beach Boys album Animal Sounds. He doesn't have the full support of his band mate but his collaborators love his innovation. The older Wilson is dealing with his mental illness and a controlling doctor Eugene Landy played by Paul Giamatti. He meets a car saleswomen Melinda played by Elizabeth Banks. She falls in love with him and will top at nothing to help him rid himself of the crazy controlling doctor Landy. Love & and Mercy is 1 of the best musical bio-pics ever. Dano and Cusack were perfectly cast as young and old Wilson. they both capture the 2 sides and time periods of Brian Wilson. I give Love & Mercy a big see-it from Dan Skip Allen
Inspiring and moving!

An incredibly remarkable film and very unique for a rock biopic! The filmmakers did an excellent job of accurately recreating the recordings of The Beach Boys albums Pet Sounds and Smile. John Cusack and Paul Dano were both exceptional in their dual performance as frontman Brian Wilson. I could see both being nominated for acting awards when awards season comes up. Definitely check it if you are a fan of The Beach Boys or rock music in general!
Brilliant, engrossing, viscerally satisfying. Loved it. Will see it again.
Just saw it. Bold and definitely unconventional . . . as is the subject Brian Wilson.
As much as I love John Cusack, his status as Movie Star detracted from the characterization of older Brian Wilson.

It's the music, it's the man, and it's proof that Hollywood can still make a meaningful, rich and compelling movie. The cast and script deliver a powerful story in a convincing manner. The studio scenes are astounding... thanks to some marvelous editing. This is one of the best movies to come along in a long time... if you are the kind of person that wants a little more out of life than Mad Max, California Earthquakes, and Marvel heroes. Not that there's anything wrong with those but...

As a lifelong diehard fan of both the beach boys ANDBrian Wilson I spent the months preceding the release of love & mercy high in anticipation & excitement. Both the casting & acting was extraordinary. I was unsure at first how john cusack's "everyday look" was going to translate into portraying Brian Wilson, but was immediately convinced by his performance . The ONLY thing keeping me from giving 5 stars & telling everyone that this is the greatest musical biopic EVER made is that I feel like the screenplay could have been MUCH better. The lack of character development with his father, carl, dennis & mike love was clearly evident, along with the complete absence of the entire 1970's decade. Obviously, a life story such as Wilson's could be made into an entire mini series, so 120 minutes leaves lots of swiss cheese in your mind, but while many (too many) scenes are showing Dano alone in a room, or cusack staring at Elizabeth banks, I feel like the relationship between his brothers & the band could have been expanded. Other than that, it was very satisfying & well done. In regards to the music, LOTS & LOTS of classics were left out, but the ones that weren't were beautifully done & extremely fun to watch being written & performed.

I used to work at Pacific Ocean Park (POP) at the same time that the Beach Boys hung out there, so I was certainly a part of that beach culture that they helped to create. After that, I kind of let go of my interest in them and moved on to the British Invasion. I only paid minimal interest in them from then until I got re-married in '99 when my bride wanted to select "Wouldn't it be nice?" has her bridal theme song. She was a fan, but knew very little about the band. Last year, we attended a Brian Wilson concert, and I grudgingly went. However, once we saw the concert, we were astounded. Something was different than any rock performance that we had ever seen. Brian was completely passive until the music started then he became alive. Clearly, something was going on that we did not understand. Since that time we have been discovering Brian's story. This film bring authentic clarity to all of it. I left this movie, and the surprise panel with Brian and Melinda, with such an uplifted feeling that I wish that I could share in words. The story could not have been told better nor performed by less of an ensemble. All I can do is enthusiastically recommend this film and wait until we can own our own copy. Bravo to the Love and Mercy team!
Great acting by everyone, but John Cusak really stands out in his portrayal.
Very intense and powerful. Brian really suffered!
This movie is a gem. Great insight into one of the greatest talents of our time.

Fantastic. Really. Most musical biopics I've seen have too much hollywood in it or consist of an agenda of over glorifying the person or something. I am a huge Brian Wilson fan, and I walked out of the theatre very happy, and I can be tough on movies. They depicted everyone very well from personality to looks (especially Van Dyke Parks on the latter)! They handled Brian being casted by 2 actors very well by bouncing back and forth between the periods in his life so you do not get too attached to one face. They filmed some sessions in Western Studios and did a great mixing job on incorporating the real session tapes in with the actors singing. Although the movie did a great job at capturing a lot of the pressure put on Brian, but they didn't mention Capitol's pressure as much as they should have, but at least they touched on it in a couple of lines. I'm glad they even took a swipe to discredit Brian's "autobiography" (which was basically his psychiatrist writing the book and portraying himself as a messiah for the entire second half of it). This movie is DEFINITELY worth seeing and they did a fantastic job at mixing (hope it gets the Oscar!) so definitely try to see it in a theatre with good sound if possible!!

Love & Mercy brings its protagonist to life in a way that few other biopics do. The schizophrenic Brian Wilson, with all of his troubles and oddities, still feels completely understandable, and that's quite a triumph. This is the kind of movie that's engaging and entertaining because of the character driven drama, not just the stuff that the people in the movie do. Dano and Cusack each craft two sides of the same person, seeming to play off of each other even though they're never seen together. Dano's version is a younger Wilson, at a creative peak and at the start of his mental issues, and Cusack plays the older Wilson, with his issues having taken hold of his life, and a struggling relationship with a new woman. This is the unconventional but extremely affective way that this biopic is told. Dano and Cusack probably share an equal amount of screen time, and this unfolds the character with twice the depth. We come to understand both Wilson's skillfully at the same time as the film switches back and forth. Knowing the man in two states, after seeing the film, feels like the only way to truly know him. I knew almost nothing about this movie, or Brian Wilson before I came into the theater. Because of this, I noticed how Wilson, as well as several other characters in the film, are revealed to us by time. If you didn't know Wilson was schizophrenic before watching, you wouldn't for quite a while into the film. It chooses to reveal its characters like how we get to know people: we see how they behave, and as we spend time with them, understand their struggles and depths. Giamatti's Eugene Landy and Elizabeth Banks's Melinda work in similar ways. Giamatti is a scene stealer as Landy, sometimes very funny, and sometimes not all after his character's motivations are revealed. Banks is excellent at convincing us of her character's emotional connection with Wilson, even though it's a seemingly strange combination. One of the film's great achievements was that I felt that I understood Wilson's schizophrenia so much that to even think of describing him as insane feels completely inappropriate. He was a creative spirit in need of solitude and freedom, and the world, as well as important people in his life, were unable to give that to him. It's extremely rare in a movie to find that level of depth in a mentally unstable character. Audiences can relate to him as artists or creative people, or just people who have too many others trying to pull them in directions away from their own.In the end, we get a clip of the real Brian Wilson singing Love & Mercy, and understand what the song means to him. This is an emotionally satisfying and entertaining movie because of how the film treats and understands its characters. Other biopics can place too much emphasis on the physical achievements of their subjects, but this one knows where the good stuff is and how to access it while avoiding conventions with ease. I think everyone will enjoy this movie and go see it.
Very slow movie. Nothing as I thought it would be.

The movie about the young genius behind Pet Sounds, one the greatest albums in the past 50 yrs. Better than I could hoped it would be. Having bought and listened to the album on release this movie made my youth come rushing back. I bought Pet Sounds based on loving the earlier Beach Boys songs but, like Mike Love, was a little taken back at first. Unlike Love, I fell in love with it after about 3 times though. This movie shows how much we may have missed hadn't his; dad, Parks, and Landry messed with him. The movie version of the Pet Sounds studio sessions totally blew me away and I had all I could do to control my emotions watching listening to them. Danno, as the Pet Sounds era Brian, hit it out of the park and deserves a best actor nomination. Danno playing Wilson during the sessions made me 100% believe we we're witnessing the genius first hand of Brian Wilson and the crack under the radar Wrecking Crew studio musicians. Cusack, for me, did a great job of portraying the older Brian but I couldn't quite get past the fact that he doesn't physically resemble Wilson, at all. With lots people likely chomping at the bit to play Wilson you would think they could have found someone else equally talented with more resemblance to Wilson. That for me was the one and only minor flaw to this awesome movie. Bill Pohlad, producer and son of deceased local billionaire & MN Twins owner Carl Pohlad was the subject of a lot of abusive commentary online after the movie was reviewed and highly rated by our local newspaper critic. Lots of jealous people basically saying "anyone with his money could make this movie". That's 150% BS!
