Bill Pohlad did a fantastic loving job of putting us right back in the 60s, 70s and 80s with Brian Wilson and the music that impacted my life and so many others. Loved it! Thanks Brian and Bill!
Finding your true sanity is a spiritual experience and this very well represents how Brian Wilson accomplished it.
Best Movie of the year. Cross between Almost Famous and Birdman.. Brilliant and devastatingly dramatic. Tragic and Triumphant. Cusack nails it. All the actors do.

A very unique screen biography, and without question the greatest and most convincing cinematic look at the creative process (as opposed to the life of the creative artist) I have ever seen. Paul Giamatti gives his finest (and scariest) screen performance--the Best Supporting Actor Oscar is his. Paul Dano as the young Brian Wilson and John Cusack as the older Brian are equally convincing and heartbreaking. Elizabeth Banks as the sympathetic "friend indeed" Melinda is also excellent, as is Jake Abel as Carl, the most pragmatic and outspoken member of the Beach Boys. I can't recommend this film highly enough.

This biopic of Brian Wilson's life covers from about the time he started working on Pet Sounds, until he was released from Landy's care, with a lot of the 70s and early 80s missing. The acting and music here, as expected, is fantastic. However, the story and the editing/directing lacked any form of subtlety. It's hard to explain in words, but all the dialogue, and all the visuals were hammering in what you were supposed to be feeling at a particular time. The story is told out in a semi-linear fashion, in that it jumps back from the 80s/90s to the 60s, but each time period is shown in order. It mostly works, although it seemed to me, "Good Vibrations" took weeks to record, not the months it actually did. Still, I can't call this bad, and it's worth watching for the performances.
Beautifully made! Give a good listen to Pet Sounds and Smile and then go see this movie.
Just loved it!! Whish I had read a little more before going. Timeline not really shown but I guess was not relevant.
Fascinating story ,difficult to tell but brilliantly scripted,crafted and acted by amazing cast.

John Cusack as Brian Wilson? Never! I wasn't able to "buy into" these actors portraying someone as complicated as Brian Wilson..so, I kind of checked out from the get goAt least Paul Dano kind of looked like a younger Brian but even still, I wasn't buying it.Not nearly enough time was spent on both the scale of his LSD usage and his incessant need to compete with the Beatles..totally glossed over these very important contributors to his eventual mental collapse.This is a made for Hollywood movie that could very easily have been an after school TV special....net net, I for one won't "Do It Again"
Unexpectedly creative filmmaking . Not your typical bio pic.

Just saw Love & Mercy and I left the theater like I was invited into the private and unknowable world of a true creative genius. It was a story that felt both tragic and redemptive. Wilson was trapped in the 1980s and you felt how hopeless his life had become. I thought I knew some fleeting details of Brian Wilson's life... but this pic made sense of the question, "what happened to Brian Wilson." If you only know the Beach Boys from their surfer hits, you must see this movie. Paul Giamatti is so despicable I wanted to get out of my seat and slap him. (Supporting actor nomination in the works?)

An amazing journey through the life, relationships and talents of the great Brian Wilson. There should be many Oscar nominations here including 2 best actor, Best Actress, best supporting actor and best Direction and script. In other words a masterpiece of the highest magnitude. The Dual performances of Dano and Cusack make it seamless and impossible to even detect. I know Brian is proud and it is satisfying to say the least to see this tortured Genius given his unanimous respect and admiration. To create this much beauty in these conditions is truly a miracle. Do not miss this one folks!

Absolutely amazing experience. I did not know much about the Beach Boys (and especially Brian Wilson's genius) prior to Love & Mercy and I doubt this film offers much new to diehard fans of either, but for me this was a proper education, an achingly nostalgic love letter to the heyday of these icons and the legacy of the complicated band leader.

Intense, complex and extraordinarily well done. Worth nominations for best picture, actor, actress, supporting actor, director, screenplay and even costume design. You will never hear the Beach Boys the same way again .
Great movie about a gifted and sensitive man. Puts tears of joy and sadness in my eyes. Both Brian Wilsons are Oscar worthy.

I've been wanting to see this since I first heard about it. and it does not disappoint. Not a perfect movie, but an exceptional one. Paul Dano and John Cusack are both great in totally different ways. And if there's a movie that captures the creation of music better than this one, I don't know what it is.

Terrific bio of Brian Wilson. At it's best when showing the details of the creative process. The casting of Cusack as the older Wilson is unfortunate though. His performances is dead, and his terrible facelift very distracting - is the one a byproduct of the other? The film is most effective as a meditation on the agony, and tragedy, of frustrated creativity.
A truly memorable movie, with amazing physical (body language) and emotional realism transferred to the screen from all types of underrated performers.
Paul Dano and John Cusack are amazing. Elizabeth Banks is as elegant as always. Paul Giamatti crushes.Love And Mercy is a must see.
Dano is great. Good film. Incredible music.

A thoroughly engaging, emotionally moving biopic about Beach Boys founder Brian Wilson at two particularly trying points in his life, expertly portrayed by Paul Dano and John Cusack. The picture's fine supporting cast, excellent period piece production values and sound quality effectively augment the film's well-crafted narrative. Easily the best picture of the year so far.
Saw Love & Mercy today and gave it an 8.5. Very intense but a powerful, good movie. I personally like John Cusack but thought his casting could be better.Paul Dano was awesome.

It is always said there is a thin line between genius and madness. This movie illustrates this principle very well. We see Brian Wilson as a young man and musical genius. We will also see him as an over medicated patient of a greedy doctor out to take him for everything he has. Brian's journey is an interesting and poignant story and the acting is superb. Paul Dano is excellent as the young Brian; John Cusack is equally as good as the older Brian/ Elizabeth Banks gives one of her best performances and proves she is more than just another pretty face. Go see this one, it's very good.

A very well done bio pic that might disappoint fans going into this thinking they are getting a Beach Boys biopic. It is more about the creative genius of the band Brian Wilson with the other "boys" pushed to the side. It is a really great character study of a man's decent into madness caused by creative stress, parental abuse, and in his later years a mid life crisis of sorts. Paul Dano is one of our great young talents blowing me away ever since Little Miss Sunshine and There Will Be Blood and this will go down as one of his best performances along with those titles. John Cusack has been winning me over with this and earlier this year in Maps to the Stars. I haven't been a huge fan of Cusack in the past but I thought he gave the older version of Wilson nice subtle moments and lovely chemistry with Elizabeth Banks who also is having a great year. Banks has always been a charmer and here she gets to use that in a very nice way as Cusack's future wife. Even with those impressive performances, I have to say the stand out performance came from Paul Giamatti. With only about 4 or 5 scenes, he really gets under your skin and gives one of his best performances this decade so far. The costumes and sets are all great judging around time periods and keeping a clear distinction from both periods through the art and camera work. I loved the documentary feel to the recording sessions in the flashbacks but I wish that they didn't film all of the flashbacks like that. That kind of cause a separation in my mind that we were really watching two different movies and it got too in the way sometimes for Dano's performance to breath. Speaking of flashbacks, they were done well to a point. Lots of modern biopics love this new trend of out of place storytelling and flashbacks thrown in at random moments but this one balances them well but it still would have been nice to watch Wilson's character progress into his madness. I really hope this movie's sound design is remembered come award season because it is really interesting and creatively done to represent the mind and madness in Wilson's head plus they really capture the Beach Boys feel with Dano doing his own singing. I don't know if this was just an issue in my theater or if my eyes were deceiving me but the movie looked really dark even in scenes where the whole room was white. Watching trailers and clips on my TV and on my computer make me feel like that was just an issue in my theater but time will tell if that was an actual issue of the movie when it comes out on DVD. I would have liked to see more of the actual Beach Boys collaborations focused upon but it did make some sense for the story this movie wanted to tell and focus on Wilson's life rather than the band's journey. Overall, it is a great acting piece and character study with a few Beach Boys songs thrown in here and there but works. I just hope we will get a Beach Boys band biopic one day to go along with this one. Also, please remind your mom/dad/grandparent/family member that this is not a sing along. Please keep that to the car ride home. Some people in my theater did not get that memo.

One of the worse and most boring movies I had to sit through, completely disjointed and totally ridiculous.
Saw it and loved it! Great movie about a great songwriter and musical genius.

This movie was a pleasant surprise. The acting was flawless and the story itself is one that keeps playing in your head long after you've left the theater.

Oscar caliber performances

Never a fan of "The Beach Boys" and their music (though I never really disliked either) this is a fascinating portrayal of member Brain Wilson. Focusing not only on his demons but genius as well from the early 60's through the mid 80's. Two great performances by Paul Dano as the younger Brian and John Cusack as the middle age Brian. I would not be shocked if each earned a best actor nod come the Academy Awards & wouldn't that be something? Along for the ride in a break-out role is the beautiful Elizabeth Banks who will virtually stop at nothing to save the man she loves. One of the best of 2015!

It could have taken the safe route and generated itself as the musical-biopic we are used to these days with linear tellings like WALK THE LINE or JERSEY BOYS. However LOVE & MERCY approaches things a bit differently... and it does it very well. John Cusack and Paul Dano deliver strong performances that fit together seamlessly as famed musician Brian Wilson. Rather than focus on the rise to fame, the film takes the path of Brian Wilson struggle with depression, schizophrenia and social anxiety. In doing so, the glitz and glamour fades as we are presented with a very human story few fail to realize is the center of what made The Beach Boys who they are. Money machine, genius, icon, chess piece... It is a brilliant and oft misunderstood life that could have had tragic ends had it not been for a chance at love that changed it all...

Excellent!!! Paul Dano and John Cusack are amazingly in tandem with "Past" and "Future" Brian (Future Brian's life could have been a little more edgy). For the most part everyone is great. Paul Giamatti is so stiff that he is a distraction. Paul Dano could easily get a huge award for this one -and- this is definitely one of Cusack's best performances and he makes the most of the part he has been given. I would have liked a little more depth in Elizabeth Bank's role, but she also made the most of what she was given.
Herb Startford said Must See this morning on Wake Up Tucson. Go! Now!

The stellar cast delivers a moving performance in one of the best bio-pics to date. It breaks from the linear mold by switching from Beach Boy Brian to Brian the lost that gives great context to the rise, fall and redemption of one of music's greatest treasures.
Lots to like in this above-average biopic, not the least of which are the excellent performances.
this is kinda artsy for a wide released biopic, but Dano & Cusack were pretty good.

With the two outstanding performances of Paul Dano and John Cusack as Brian Wilson, Love and Mercy veers away from the ordinaries of biopics and succeeds as a richly rewarding drama for norms and Beach boy fans

Brilliant! Audacious and loving treatment of the life and music of Brian Wilson. It''s hard to say who's the better Brian, Paul Dano or John Cusack. Each captures the genius, neorosis, and gentleness of Wilson in two very different times in his life.

I was able to see Love & Mercy on Tuesday. It was even better than I first thought it was going to be. When I first heard that 2 actors were going to portray Brian Wilson, I was skeptical. Now that I've seen it, I realize how wrong I was to doubt the creative brilliance of director Bill Pohland. both Paul Dano and John Cusack give amazingly spot on portrayals of Brian Wilson. Also giving great performances were Paul Giamatti as Eugene Landy and Elizabeth Banks as Melinda Ledbetter. I know that the film has been edited a bit from it's original debut at the Toronto International Film Festival last year or so I believe. I am very satisfied with the cut I saw. I couldn't be more enthusiastic to encourange people to see this film. I cannot wait to see it again (and again).
This is a wonderful movie that shows exactly the pains an artist goes through, even if he is only creating pop tunes, and though few have gone through what Brian Wilson has.

I really enjoyed Love and Mercy. Paul Dano was excellent. He really captured the look and expressions of Brian Wilson. Even though John Cusack is a terrific actor, it was distracting since he looks absolutely nothing like either Brian Wilson or Paul Dano. Out of all the thousands of actors, they couldn't find someone who would be more fitting for the role?

Saw this as a premier last nite..at first it felt plodding along and i was not being a big fan of the beach boys or know the whole history of Brian Wilson..bit disappointed thru half of this that there wasn't much background as to how the group began..not a lot in the way of their music..and so many missing pieces..that one not being a music buff as to Wilson and the beach boy felt lacking.. But by 3/4 thru it..i got the point of it that this was Brian WIlson's story his genius and his trials not so much the group in itself.. I really realized by the film how much Wilson put into his sound his brilliance in having multiple sounds and his tireless quest for perfection. Again..it felt lacking as to his background ..his dad, how his brothers fit in ..how he ended up in a bed for almost 3 yrs ..how he grew huge in gouging himself..lots missing..but there was enough going on mentally that you did not need all those details..and i was blown away by the female who saved him ..but i had to ask why had no one intervened who cared before her.. so again..questions and voids. The actor playing the young brian was awesome..wasn't so impressed by Cusack..just ok. So i think i all in all this was haunting and made me want to know more about Brian Wilson's life story and give him more respect as i was not into the cali surfer type music in my youth.

After financing it himself out of pocket, Pohlad has successfully done the impossible and given us the Brian Wilson biopic the world deserves. Love and Mercy is a film as beautiful and imaginative in its storytelling as the music. Pohlad, as the director of only his second feature, does an assured and ambitious job of dramatic condensation while keeping his ear to the studio door and our minds on the greatness of the music. Shown working feverishly on Pet Sounds or extricating himself from Dr. Landy, the film does justice to Brian's spirit and creativity in a way that is artistic My prediction is that this is nominated for a best picture, best director and best screenplay Oscars in 2016.
Great cast! Coming soon to a theater near you!
